(5)  The city shall have the right to inspect records and the right to audit the books and records of a grantee, its affiliates, and any other person that constitutes a cable operator of the system to ensure compliance with this section. The grantee shall be responsible for providing to the city all records necessary to confirm the accurate payment of franchise fees, without regard to by whom they are held. The grantee shall maintain such records for a period of at least 6 years. A grantee shall not be entitled to withhold any such materials on the grounds that they are proprietary or confidential. 
(6)  The franchise fee paid to the city by a grantee is compensation for the use and occupation of the public rights-of-way of the city in the operation of the cable system. Payment of the franchise fee shall not be considered in the nature of a tax and shall be in addition to any other tax or payment owed to the city by the grantee such as property taxes, licenses or other fees. No grantee may designate the franchise fee as a tax in any communication to a cable subscriber. 
(7)  The franchise fee revenues received by the city shall be directed to the cost of franchise administration, operation of PEG access television, and communications and media operations of the city. 
(8)  Acceptance of any payment by the city shall not be construed as a release or act as an accord or satisfaction, or in any respect waive the city's right to collect the full amount owed. 
(9)  For purposes of calculating franchise fee payments under applicable franchise provisions, any discount reflected in an aggregated bill for services which include cable services will be allocated in a manner consistent with applicable law, and in the absence of such law, proportionately to cable services provided by the grantee. Such proportional allocations shall be made by the grantee in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP). 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02; Ord. No. 7-05, § 1, 3-21-05) 
2:112. - Insurance. 
(1)  Prior to the beginning of any franchise agreement term, a grantee shall obtain, and shall require its contractors to obtain, insurance as set forth below. The grantee must file certificates evidencing its coverage with the city. Such insurance shall be maintained in full force and effect until the end of the franchise agreement term. A franchise agreement shall not commence unless and until the grantee has the required insurance and files the required certificates, and a franchise agreement may be terminated by the city if the grantee fails to maintain the required insurance in effect. In the alternative, a grantee may satisfy this requirement through a program of self-insurance acceptable to the City Administrator or his/her designee. A grantee that wants its program of self-insurance to be accepted must provide reasonable evidence of its financial resources to the city, as well as any other relevant information requested by the city. The city's acceptance of such self-insurance shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(a)  Commercial general liability insurance, including completed operations liability, independent contractors liability, contractual liability coverage, railroad protective coverage and coverage for property damage from perils of explosion, collapse or damage to underground utilities, commonly known as XCU coverage, in an amount not less than $5,000,000.00. 
(b)  Liability insurance for sudden and accidental environmental contamination with minimum limits of $500,000.00 and providing coverage for claims discovered within 3 years after the term of the policy. 
(c)  Automobile liability insurance in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00. 
(d)  Workers' compensation and employer's liability insurance with statutory limits, and any applicable federal insurance of a similar nature. 
(e)  The coverage amounts set forth above may be met by a combination of underlying (primary) and umbrella policies so long as in combination the limits equal or exceed those stated. If more than 1 insurance policy is purchased to provide the coverage amounts set forth above, then all policies providing coverage limits excess to the primary policy shall provide drop down coverage to the first dollar of coverage and other contractual obligations of the primary policy, should the primary policy carrier not be able to perform any of its contractual obligations or not be collectible for any of its coverages for any reason during the term of the grantee's franchise agreement, or, when longer, for as long as coverage could have been available pursuant to the terms and conditions of the primary policy. 
(2)  The city shall be named as an additional insured on all policies other than worker's compensation and employer's liability. All insurance policies shall provide that they shall not be canceled, modified or not renewed unless the insurance carrier provides 30 days prior written notice to the city. A grantee shall annually provide the city with a certificate of insurance evidencing such coverage. All insurance policies other than environmental contamination, workers' compensation and employer's liability insurance shall be written on an occurrence basis and not on a claims made basis. 
(3)  All insurance shall be issued by insurance carriers licensed to do business by the State of Michigan or by surplus line carriers on the Michigan Insurance Commission approved list of companies qualified to do business in Michigan. All insurance and surplus line carriers shall be rated A+ or better by A.M. Best Company. 
(4)  If the insurance policies required by this section 2:112 are written with retainages or deductibles in excess of $50,000.00, they shall be approved by the City Administrator or his/her designee in advance in writing. A grantee shall indemnify and save harmless the city from and against the payment of any deductible and from the payment of any premium on any insurance policy required to be furnished hereunder. 
(5)  A grantee's contractors and subcontractors working in the public rights-of-way shall carry in full force and effect commercial general liability, environmental contamination liability, automobile liability and workers' compensation and employer liability insurance which complies with all terms of this section 2:112. In the alternative, a grantee, at its expense, may provide such coverages for any or all its contractors or subcontractors. This may be done by adding them to the grantee's policies. 
(6)  The grantee's insurance coverage shall be primary insurance with respect to the city, its officers, agents, employees, elected and appointed officials, departments, boards, and commissions (collectively "them"). Any insurance or self-insurance maintained by any of them shall be in excess of the grantee's insurance and shall not contribute to it. As used in this section, "insurance or self-insurance maintained by any of them" includes any contract or agreement providing any type of indemnification or defense obligation provided to, or for the benefit of them, from any source, and includes any self-insurance program or policy, or self-insured retention or deductible by, for or on behalf of them. 
(7)  A grantee shall immediately advise the City Attorney of any claim or litigation that may result in liability to the city. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:113. - Use of channels. 
(1)  In addition to providing the access channels required in section 2:114, a grantee shall provide and activate a direct fiber connection from the city's main PEG access center to the cable headend (the location where PEG programming is inserted on the subscriber network), with the capability to transmit all the city's programming for the PEG capacity specified in section 2:114, consistent with at least EIA/TIA-250C medium-haul standards, including transmission of any captioning, stereo audio, and second audio programs (SAP). 
(2)  The obligation to activate the capacity referred to in section 2:113(1) includes the obligation to provide and maintain all equipment required to transmit the signal(s) beginning with baseband signals from the city's main PEG access center into the system through the point of output. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:114. - PEG access. 
(1)  The grantee shall make available to all subscribers on the cable system at least 4 channels for public, educational, and government access use throughout the franchise term and any extensions thereof. All access channels required under this section must be provided by the grantee during the term of the franchise to subscribers of any basic cable service tier. 
(2)  In the event that the grantee delivers all other channels on the cable system in a digital format to all subscribers, it will also deliver any PEG channels in a digital format, and the following additional requirements shall apply: 
(a)  If any access channels are provided to the grantee in a high-definition television format compatible with a format used on the grantee's cable system, the grantee shall carry such access channels in a form that preserves such enhanced quality, using any applicable compression or other techniques at no lower level of quality than it applies to other channels on its system. 
(b)  In addition to those access channels specified in section 2:114(1), which may be carried as specified in section 2:114(2) and 2:114(2)(a), the city may request, and each grantee shall provide, additional bandwidth for PEG purposes up to a maximum of 6 MHz of additional bandwidth. Such PEG bandwidth shall only be requested and provided, however, if the cable commission reasonably determines that (i) the use serves a public, educational, or governmental purpose, and (ii) there is an identified community need or interest in the proposed PEG programming of service; and the grantee reasonably determines that (iii) the proposed use is non-commercial in nature and (iv) the proposed use does not substantially duplicate programming otherwise available on the grantee's cable system. 
(3)  Unless agreed otherwise by the city and the grantee, (i) the PEG channels specified in section 2:114(1) shall be made available on the lowest basic tier offered by the grantee and at a channel position no higher than 45; alternatively, (ii) if additional bandwidth is used pursuant to section 2:114(2)(b), the PEG channels or uses shall be displayed in a contiguous block; and (iii) channel positions shall be the same throughout the city. Without limiting the provisions of the previous 2 sentences, access channel assignments may be changed in the grantee's sole discretion, but may not be changed more often than once every 2 years or more often than 4 times over the life of the renewed franchise without the city's consent. Any such repositioning must be to a channel of technical quality at least equivalent to that of other channels on the system. In any repositioning, grantee shall give as much notice of the planned repositioning to the city as is practical, but not less than 60 days of advance notice. The grantee shall reimburse the city for actual unavoidable expenses incurred in repositioning channels, on account of any necessary change in equipment, promotional materials, office supplies and the like, in an amount not to exceed an aggregate of $5,000.00. In addition, in the event of repositioning, the grantee will cooperate with city in an effort to inform subscribers of the change, and will provide reasonable services such as cross channel promotion, subscriber notices, and scrolled channel messages. 
(4)  The city shall operate the access channels specified in section 2:114(1), (2). 
(5)  A grantee is prohibited from censoring any PEG programming which is cablecast, except to the extent that federal law allows. 
(6)  A grantee shall provide a capital grant to the city (the "PEG Capital Facilities Grant") as specified in the franchise agreement, to be used by the city, in its sole discretion, in a manner consistent with 47 U.S.C. § 542(g)(2)(C). 
(a)  In any franchise agreement the city shall obtain commitments from that grantee to provide capital grants that total at least 2% of that grantee's gross revenues. 
(b)  A grantee shall make its capital grant payments quarterly at the same time and in the same manner as its franchise fee payments, unless otherwise provided in its franchise agreement. 
(c)  Any real or personal property acquired by the city through the PEG capital facilities grant and used for or in support of PEG access, shall be the property of the city. 
(7)  The city shall require all users of the public access facilities or channels to indemnify and hold harmless the city and the grantee from any and all liability or other injury (including the reasonable cost of defending claims or litigation) arising from or in connection with claims for failure to comply with applicable laws, rules, regulations or other requirements of local, state, or federal authorities, including but not limited to claims of libel, slander, obscenity, invasion of privacy, or the infringement of common law or statutory copyright; unauthorized use of any trademark, trade name or service mark; breach of contractual or other obligations owing to third parties by the grantee or the city; and any other injury, damages or penalties which result from the use of the public access channels or facilities. All such users shall be required to agree to such indemnification in writing prior to use of a public access facility or channel. The form of the indemnification shall be reasonably acceptable to a grantee. 
(8)  All payments made under this section are not franchise fee payments and fall within 1 of the exceptions to 47 U.S.C. Section 542(g). 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:115. - Rules, records and reports. 
(1)  The city shall have full and complete access to any of the grantee's records that relate to the city's lawful rights or authority under this chapter or other applicable law or agreements, including without limitation customer service issues. Such records may include, but are not limited to, all books, receipts, maps, performance test results, plans, contracts, engineering, accounting, financial, statistical, customer and service records, and reports to stockholders, in whatever manner kept. Upon reasonable notice, the grantee shall make its books and records available for inspection by the city or to designated representatives at the local office or, by mutual agreement of the city and the grantee, at another location within 25 miles of the city. The city shall have the right to inspect any such records, and may copy any such records except that if grantee reasonably asserts that non-financial records not covered by section 2:111 are trade secrets or confidential and proprietary, then the grantee need not consent to copying under this chapter unless city covenants that confidential and proprietary information copied will not be subject to public disclosure. This includes not only the books and records of the grantee, but any books and records the city reasonably deems relevant that are held by an affiliate, a cable operator of the cable system, or any contractor, subcontractor or any person holding any form of management contract for the cable system. 
(2)  On or before the 61st day following the end of each calendar year, each grantee shall file with the city an annual report including the following upon the city's request if made before the end of the previous year: 
(a)  A summary of written complaints (including those received by e-mail or recorded in writing by the grantee), identifying both the number and nature of the complaints received and an explanation of their dispositions, as such records are kept by the grantee. Where complaints involve recurrent cable system problems, the nature of each problem and the corrective measures taken shall be identified: 
(b)  A summary of the results of, and/or, at the grantee's option, copies of the cable system's technical tests and measurements performed during the past year; 
(c)  A summary of the cable system's reliability, and the reliability of any cable modem service delivered, if different; 
(d)  A copy of updated as-built maps depicting the location of all cable plant (including I-Net plant), showing areas served and locations of all trunk lines and feeder lines in the city, including changes in all such items for the period of the report, and including GIS files in a format established by the Michigan Public Service Commission or acceptable to the city; 
(e)  A full schedule of all generally applicable subscriber rates, fees, and charges; 
(f)  The grantee's policies regarding subscriber privacy; 
(g)  Such other information as the city may from time to time request with respect to the operation, of the grantee's cable system and service within the city. 
(3)  Within 10 days of the adoption of any written policies, practices, procedures, terms or conditions significantly impacting subscribers, grantee shall file a copy of such rules, regulations, terms or conditions with the city. 
(4)  A grantee shall submit to the city a monthly subscriber activity report within 20 days from the end of the preceding month, including: 
(a)  Number of subscribers for each type of cable service. 
(b)  Trouble code resolution data, pursuant to the form attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter as Addendum A. 
(c)  Outage report, pursuant to the form attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter as Addendum B. 
(d)  A report detailing the grantee's gross revenues for the month, including a breakdown by type of service, pursuant to the form attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter as Addendum C. 
(e)  The percentage of time the grantee's call center telephone trunk(s) serving Ann Arbor are busy. 
(f)  The percentage of calls to the grantee's call center serving Ann Arbor that are answered within 30 seconds. 
(g)  The percentage of installations in Ann Arbor completed within 7 business days of the request from a subscriber. 
(h)  The number of service call windows missed as a percentage of all service calls in Ann Arbor. 
(i)  A breakdown of the number of service complaints by type. 
(j)  An overview of the promotional offers generally made available during the month in the franchise area. 
(5)  The city may request further information regarding the points covered in this report pursuant to section 2:115(1). 
(6)  If the information provided pursuant to section 2:115(4) does not take into account any exclusion for periods not under normal operating conditions, the grantee shall so inform the city in its monthly report, and the grantee will provide upon request the corresponding information adjusted for any such exclusion. 
(7)  A grantee shall annually provide, within 120 days of the close of its fiscal year, an unaudited balance sheet and income statement of grantee for the preceding fiscal year, certified by an officer of the grantee as true and accurate to the best of his or her knowledge and belief. In addition, the grantee shall furnish a statement of revenues for its operations in the city for the same fiscal period, which shall be furnished with the unaudited fiscal statements referred to above. The report shall be in a form suitable for the city to accomplish the review of basic rates and the audit and review of gross revenues and franchise fee and PEG capital facilities grants made pursuant to the grantee's franchise. The statement of revenues shall separate grantee's revenues between basic service, cable programming services, premium services, and other sources of revenue, including a breakdown of revenue by type of service. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:116. - Rates. 
(1)  The city may regulate rates except as prohibited by state or federal law. 
(2)  Except to the extent it would be prohibited from doing so by state or federal law, at all times the grantee shall notify the city and all subscribers at least 30 days in advance before adding additional services, or if it proposes to materially alter existing services. 
(3)  The provisions of this section govern the regulation of rates for basic service and equipment within the city for any grantee subject to rate regulation by the city pursuant to applicable law. The provisions set forth below are intended to be consistent with all Federal Communications Commission "FCC") regulations governing the regulation of basic service rates and equipment, and the city will regulate and interpret its rules so that they are consistent with FCC regulations, as if those regulations were set forth in full herein. If any provision of these regulations shall, to any extent, be held to be invalid, unenforceable, or preempted by federal law or regulation, the remainder hereof shall be valid in all other respects and continue to be effective. The grantee is prohibited from engaging in any activity it is prohibited from engaging in under FCC rules and regulations, as if those rules and regulations were set forth in full herein. For purposes of these provisions, the term "basic service" or "basic cable service" has the same meaning as the term "basic service" at 47 C.F.R. § 76.901 and the term "equipment" refers to all equipment and services subject to regulation under 47 C.F.R. § 76.923(a)(1). No delay or failure to enforce any provision of these regulations shall operate against the city as an estoppel or waiver. 
(4)  Rate filings. 
(a)  Initial rate filings. A grantee that is notified that its basic service and equipment rates are subject to regulation must file a submission ("initial rate filing") within 30 days of the notification, except to the extent otherwise specifically provided by governing law. The initial rate filing shall justify the grantee's basic service and equipment rates in accordance with FCC rules. All rates, for all customer classifications, must be justified, except to the extent that such rates are specifically exempted from regulation by FCC regulations or other governing law. 
(b)  Subsequent rate filings. 
(i)  Once a grantee has been notified by the city that its rates are subject to regulation, it may not thereafter increase its rates for basic service or equipment without making any rate filings required by applicable law and obtaining such prior approval of the city as may be required under governing regulations. This requirement applies in all cases, including with respect to increases in rates announced prior to the date the operator was notified its rates were subject to regulation where the increases were not implemented prior to the date of notice, except insofar as governing law specifically permits a grantee to raise rates without prior approval. 
(ii)  In addition, a grantee must submit a rate filing at any other time such a filing is required under FCC rules, or by the city in accordance with such rules. 
(iii)  For purposes of this section, a "rate increase" occurs when there is either an increase in rates, or a new basic service or equipment rate, or a decrease in program or customer services without a corresponding decrease in rates. 
(iv)  Rate filings proposing and supporting rate increases must be filed for review at least 30 days in advance of the proposed effective date of the increase. This requirement does not alter or eliminate any other notice requirement. 
(v)  A grantee shall provide at least 30 days' notice (or such longer period as may be specified in FCC regulations) to subscribers and to the city of any proposed changes in basic service tier or equipment rates, whether or not the grantee believes the affected rates are subject to regulation, except to the extent such notice requirement is specifically waived by governing law. 
(c)  Filing: where made. Every rate filing must be submitted to the cable administrator. A rate filing shall be considered filed for review on the date a facially complete rate filing is received by the cable administrator. Information that the grantee claims is proprietary under section 2:116(4)(d)(iii)(B) must be clearly identified and segregated from the remainder of the filing and clearly marked so that the city may determine where and how the proprietary information was used to determine rates. 
(d)  Filing: contents. 
(i)  Subject to any FCC regulations governing the burden of proof, a rate filing submitted by a grantee must show that the rates the grantee proposes to charge for basic service and equipment are reasonable pursuant to applicable FCC regulations. 
(ii)  The rate filing must contain all applicable FCC forms. 
(iii)  Every rate filing must clearly state in a cover letter: 
(A)  Any changes the rate filing proposes, in the form of a brief, narrative description of any proposed changes in rates or in service; 
(B)  Whether any pages of the rate filing contain information that the grantee claims is proprietary, listing any such pages. 
(5)  Review of rate filings. 
(a)  Receipt and notice of rate filings. 
(i)  After receiving a rate filing, the city promptly shall publish a notice that a filing has been received and that, except for those parts which may be withheld as proprietary, it is available for public review. The notice shall state that interested parties may comment on the filing, and shall provide interested parties a reasonable time, in light of the dates by which the City Council must issue its orders, to submit written comments on the filing to the Cable Communications Commission. 
(ii)  The grantee shall notify the city as soon as possible of any deficiencies it may discover in a rate filing, and shall submit an amended filing in accordance with the filing requirements of section 2:116(4)(c), (d) as soon as possible (and in any event within 5 business days, unless the city waives this deadline) to cure such deficiencies, together with a full explanation of the deficiencies and the correction. However, the provisions of subsection 2:116(5)(a)(i) shall not apply to any refilings or corrected filings made by a grantee to replace, amend, or supplement an initial rate filing. 
(b)  Final rate order. 
(i)  After completing its review of a grantee's rate filing and any additional information submitted in response to information requests, the cable administrator may submit any comments received and the cable administrator's recommendations for action to the City Administrator. The City Administrator may make recommendations to the City Council and, if so, shall make the City Administrator's recommendations available for public inspection. When such recommendations are submitted, the City Administrator may set a reasonable deadline by which the grantee may submit a response to public comments or to the City Administrator's recommendations. The grantee's response shall be filed with the cable administrator, and if it is submitted in a timely fashion, the cable administrator shall forward a copy to the City Council. 
(ii)  After reviewing the City Administrator's recommendations, the City Council may issue a written order, which may be in any lawful form, approving the proposed rate in whole or in part, or denying the proposed rate in whole or in part and determining maximum permitted rates pursuant to applicable FCC regulations. 
(iii)  The City Administrator may make partial recommendations regarding particular rates, and the City Council may issue partial orders setting particular rates and ordering refunds and other appropriate relief with regard to such rates, consistent with the Cable Act, without prejudice to their right to make further recommendations and issue further orders in accordance with applicable FCC regulations. 
(c)  Refunds. If a rate order determines that refunds should be provided to subscribers, the grantee shall file with the cable administrator, within the time period specified in that order, a detailed calculation of the appropriate refunds, including interest, to all relevant classes of subscribers, and a description of its proposed refund methodology, together with all supporting materials necessary to allow the cable administrator to verify the grantee's calculations. The grantee's calculations shall also show, in detail, how the grantee proposes to calculate any portion of the refund properly attributable to franchise fees. The cable administrator may require further supporting information with regard to the grantee's calculations, and the grantee must provide all such information reasonably necessary to determine the refund and franchise fee amounts. 
(d)  Provisions generally applicable to rate orders. 
(i)  Orders relating to rate regulation ("rate orders") shall be written and may be issued in any lawful form. 
(ii)  Any rate order that establishes maximum permitted rates for basic cable service, equipment or installation, or requires refunds to cable subscribers ("final rate order"), shall be issued by the City Council. Any other orders, including without limitation (1) orders that toll deadlines for review and (2) orders that allow rates to take effect subject to refund and/or direct a cable operator to keep an accurate account of all amounts received and on whose behalf such amounts were paid, pursuant to 47 C.F.R. § 76.933(a)-(c), may be issued by the cable administrator. 
(iii)  Each final rate order shall be released to the public and the grantee, and a public notice shall be published stating that the final rate order has been issued and is available for review. 
(iv)  The city may take any actions that are consistent with the rate regulation authority delegated to it by the Cable Act or governing regulations. 
(v)  Notice and opportunity to comment. Before prescribing a rate or ordering a refund to subscribers, the City Council shall ensure the grantee has had notice and opportunity to comment on the proposed rate or refunds. If the recommendations of the City Administrator propose a refund or a rate, then mailing a copy of the recommendation to the grantee at the time it is submitted to the City Council shall be deemed to provide the grantee this notice, and the grantee must comment on the refund or rate in its response to the recommendations. 
(vi)  No order approving or setting a rate pursuant to FCC regulations shall be deemed to establish a just and reasonable rate to subscribers. Every such rate approved or established shall be subject to further reduction and refund to the extent permitted under applicable laws and regulations, as the same may be amended from time to time. By way of illustration and not limitation, should the FCC revise its rules for calculating the maximum permitted rates, the city shall have the right to reduce a grantee's rates and to require the grantee to refund any amounts collected above the benchmark, except to the extent prohibited by governing law. 
(6)  Grantees' duties. 
(a)  It is each grantee's duty to submit as complete a rate filing as possible, and knowingly withholding information or making a filing that is incomplete under applicable law shall be treated as a violation of this chapter, subject to any applicable sanctions and remedies under FCC regulations, this chapter, and any other applicable law or contract. 
(b)  Each grantee is responsible for the continuing accuracy and completeness of information furnished to the city. Whenever information furnished by a grantee is no longer accurate and complete in all significant respects, the grantee shall correct such deficiencies as required herein. 
(c)  A grantee must respond to requests for information from the cable administrator by reasonable deadlines established by the cable administrator (including requests that specified information be submitted at the time of future rate filings). A grantee is responsible for ensuring that any other entity that has records of revenues or expenses that are allocated to the grantee's system responds to the cable administrator's requests. 
(d)  A grantee must implement remedial requirements, including prospective rate reductions and refunds, as soon as possible after an order requiring such remedies is issued, but in any case within 60 days of the date the City Council issues an order mandating a remedy. However, if FCC regulations require the grantee to implement a remedy more quickly, or require that the grantee be allowed more time to implement a remedy, then the FCC requirement shall control. 
(e)  Within 30 days after implementing a remedy, but in no event more than 90 days after the date an order mandating a remedy is issued, a grantee must file a certification, signed by an authorized representative of the grantee: 
(i)  Stating whether the grantee has complied fully with all provisions of the City Council's order; 
(ii)  Describing in detail the precise measures taken to implement the City Council's order; and 
(iii)  Describing in detail any respects in which the grantee has not complied fully with all provisions of the City Council's order; and 
(iv)  Showing how any applicable refunds (including interest) were calculated and distributed. 
(7)  The City Administrator or his/her designee shall be responsible for administering the provisions of section 2:116. Without limitation and by way of illustration, the City Administrator or his/her designee: 
(a)  Shall ensure notices are given to the public and each grantee as required herein and by FCC regulations. 
(b)  May submit requests for information to the grantee and establish deadlines for response to them, as provided herein. 
(c)  For good cause, may waive any provision herein or extend any deadline for filing or response except as to such matters as are mandatory under FCC regulations. 
(d)  Shall rule on any request for confidentiality. 
(e)  Shall prepare the recommendations to the City Council contemplated by this section. 
(8)  If the City Administrator recommends that any increase be denied in whole or in part, he/she shall: 
(a)  Propose a rate and explain the basis for the recommendation (it may propose that rates remain at existing levels); and 
(b)  Recommend whether and on what basis refunds should be issued; and 
(c)  Notify the grantee of the recommendation at the time it is submitted to the City Council. 
(9)  Except as prohibited by federal law, a grantee shall be subject to penalties and forfeitures under this chapter, and its request for approval of a rate may be denied if it: 
(a)  Knowingly submits false or fraudulent information to the city in connection with any rate proceeding; 
(b)  Fails to comply with any lawful order or request of the city, including, but not limited to, a request for information or an order setting rates; or 
(c)  Evades or attempts to evade federal or local rate regulation; provided that, filing for approval of a rate that is later determined to be unreasonable is not in and of itself an evasion of federal or local rate regulation. 
(10)  Disclosure of information. 
(a)  All materials filed with the city in connection with rate regulation shall be subject to release, or exemption from release, in accordance with applicable federal and state law. 
(b)  Information that the operator claims is proprietary must be clearly identified. If it is part of a larger submission, such as a rate filing, the proprietary information must be segregated from the remainder of the submission. It must also be clearly marked so that the city may determine where the proprietary information belongs within the submission, how it relates to the remainder of the submission, and the basis for the grantee's claim that the marked material is proprietary. 
(c)  The cable administrator shall promptly, and before any decision as to any release of such information, notify the grantee in writing of any request to release material the operator claims is proprietary. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:117. - Necessity of franchise and application process. 
(1)  No person shall own or operate a cable system in the city except by franchise expressly issued by the city granting such power to any such grantee. 
(2)  A written application shall be filed with the city for the grant of an initial franchise or modification of a franchise agreement pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 545. To be acceptable for filing, a signed original of the application shall be submitted together with 6 copies. The application must be accompanied by any required application filing fee, conform to any applicable request for proposals, and contain all required information. All applications shall include the names and addresses of persons authorized to act on behalf of all applicants with respect to the application. An application that does not conform to the applicable requirements of this section may be rejected by the city, without prejudice to the applicant's ability to file a corrected, conforming application. 
(3)  Initial application for a franchise. The grant of an initial franchise shall require, and any such application shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
(a)  Name and address of the applicant and identification of the ownership and control of the applicant, including the names and addresses of the 10 largest holders of an ownership interest in the applicant and affiliates of the applicant, and all persons with 5% or more ownership interest in the applicant and its affiliates; the person who controls the applicant and its affiliates; all officers of the applicant and its affiliates; and any other business affiliation and cable system ownership interest in each named person. 
(b)  Information that demonstrates the applicant's technical ability to construct and/or operate the proposed cable system, including identification of key personnel. 
(c)  Information that demonstrates the applicant's legal qualifications to construct and/or operate the proposed cable system. 
(d)  A statement prepared by a certified public accountant demonstrating the applicant's financial ability to complete construction and commence operation of the cable system proposed. 
(e)  A description of the applicant's prior experience in cable system ownership, construction, and operation, and identification of at least 5 communities in which the applicant or any of the principals have, or have had, a cable franchise or any interest therein. 
(f)  A detailed description of the physical facilities proposed, including channel capacity and performance characteristics. 
(g)  A description of the construction of the proposed system, including an estimate of plant mileage and its location; the proposed construction schedule; a description, where appropriate, of how services will be converted from existing facilities to new facilities; and information on the availability of space in conduits including, where appropriate, an estimate of the cost of any necessary rearrangement of existing facilities. 
(h)  A demonstration of how the applicant will reasonably meet the future cable-related needs and interests of the community, including descriptions of how the applicant will meet the needs described in any recent community needs assessment conducted by or for the city, and how the applicant will provide adequate PEG access channel capacity, facilities, or financial support to meet the community's needs and interests. 
(i)  If the applicant proposes to provide cable service to an area already served by an existing cable franchise, the identification of the area where the overbuild would occur and the ability of the public rights-of-way and other property that would be used by the applicant to accommodate an additional system. 
(j)  Any other information that may be reasonably necessary to demonstrate compliance with the requirements of this chapter. 
(k)  Any additional information that the city may request of the applicant that is relevant to the city's consideration of the application. 
(l)  An affidavit or declaration of the applicant or authorized officer certifying the truth and accuracy of the information in the application, acknowledging the enforceability of application commitments, and certifying that the application meets all federal and state law requirements. 
(m)  The following optional items may also be included at the applicant's discretion: 
(i)  The proposed rate structure, including projected charges for each service, installation, converters, and all other proposed equipment or services. 
(ii)  Pro forma financial projections for the proposed franchise term, including a statement of projected income, and a schedule of planned capital additions, with all significant assumptions explained in notes or supporting schedules. 
(4)  Application for grant of a renewal franchise. The renewal of a franchise to provide cable service shall be conducted in a manner consistent with applicable law. 
(5)  Application for modification of a franchise. An application for a modification of a franchise agreement shall include, at a minimum, the following information: 
(a)  The specific modification requested. 
(b)  The justification for the requested modification, including the impact of the requested modification on subscribers and others, and the financial impact on the applicant if the modification is approved or disapproved, demonstrated through submission of financial pro formas. 
(c)  A statement whether the modification is sought pursuant to Section 625 of the Cable Act, 47 U.S.C. § 545, and, if so, a demonstration that the requested modification meets the standards set forth in 47 U.S.C. § 545, as it may from time to time be amended. 
(d)  Any other information that the applicant believes is necessary for the city to make an informed determination on the application for the modification. 
(e)  An affidavit or declaration of the applicant or authorized officer certifying the truth and accuracy of the information in the application, and certifying that the application is consistent with all federal and state law requirements. 
(6)  An application for an initial franchise or for modification shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable filing fee, payable to the city, in the amount of $5,000.00. In addition, the city may require the applicant to reimburse the city for its reasonable out-of-pocket expenses in considering the application, including consultants' fees, up to a maximum of $45,000.00 including the $5,000.00 filing fee, which shall be due no later than 30 days after they are invoiced by the city. Payments made by an applicant hereunder shall not be considered a franchise fee or offset against franchise fees. 
(7)  Provisions applicable to all applications under this section. 
(a)  The city may, for good cause shown, waive in writing the provision of any of the information required by this section. 
(b)  The city may request such additional information as may reasonably be required regarding an application, and an applicant shall cooperate promptly with such requests. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the city from requesting or obtaining any information after the application is filed. 
(c)  Public hearings. An applicant shall be notified of any public hearings held in connection with the evaluation of its application and shall be given an opportunity to be heard. Prior to the issuance of a franchise, the city shall provide for the holding of a public hearing within the proposed franchise area, following reasonable notice to the public, at which the applicant and its application shall be examined and the public and all interested parties afforded a reasonable opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:118. - Construction, maintenance, and operation of facilities. 
(1)  System tests and inspections. 
(a)  The grantee shall perform all tests reasonably necessary to demonstrate compliance with the requirements of the franchise agreement, this chapter, and other performance standards established by law or regulation or by a franchise agreement, and to ensure that the system components are operating as expected. All tests shall be conducted in accordance with federal rules where applicable. 
(b)  The city may also conduct inspections of all parts of the system (including without limitation any I-Net), including but not limited to inspections to assess compliance with FCC technical standards and generally applicable construction and safety codes. Inspection does not relieve the grantee of its obligation to build in compliance with all provisions of the franchise. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to conduct its own tests upon reasonable notice to the grantee. The city will endeavor to arrange any request for such tests so as to minimize hardship or inconvenience to the grantee or to subscribers. 
(d)  The results of any tests or technical reports required by the FCC shall be filed with the city upon request, within 2 weeks after such request. The grantee shall retain in writing such results. 
(e)  If any test indicates that any part or component of the system fails to meet applicable requirements, the grantee, without requirement of additional notice or request from the city, shall take corrective action, retest the locations and advise the city of the action taken and results achieved. 
(2)  Publicizing proposed construction work. The grantee shall notify the public prior to commencing any proposed construction that will significantly disturb or disrupt public property or have the potential to present a danger or affect the safety of the public generally. The grantee shall publicize proposed construction work at least 1 week prior to commencement of that work by causing written notice of such construction work to be delivered to the city and by notifying those persons most likely to be affected by the work in at least 2 of the following ways: by telephone, in person, by mail, by distribution of flyers to residences, by publication in local newspapers, or in any other manner reasonably calculated to provide adequate notice. In addition, before entering onto any person's property (except in case of an emergency, including emergency repairs), the grantee shall make reasonable efforts to contact the property owner or (in the case of residential property) the resident in advance. 
(3)  Compliance with FCC rules. All maintenance performed on the cable system by the grantee shall be in accordance with the FCC rules and regulations governing the technical performance and operating standards for such system where applicable. 
(4)  Audio. All programming transmitted by the system, including PEG access programming, that contains stereo audio or closed-captioning shall include such features as provided by the program originator without substantial alteration or deterioration. Any PEG access facility interconnection links shall also be constructed and operated so that any such audio features included by the program originator shall be included in the programming as received by subscribers. 
(5)  A grantee shall ensure that hearing impaired customers can contact the company by TDD/TTY or equivalent methods. 
(6)  A grantee shall promulgate and adhere to a preventive maintenance policy directed toward maximizing the reliability (mean time between malfunctions) and maintainability (mean time to repair) of its cable system. A grantee shall maintain a repair department comprised of trained technicians, service vehicles and equipment to provide quality repair service. Service shall be rendered efficiently and repairs made promptly. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:119. - Signal quality requirements. 
(1)  A grantee shall: 
(a)  Transmit signals capable of producing a picture, whether in black and white or color, that do not exhibit noticeable disturbances such as ghost images, crosstalk, and intermodulation products, and accompanied with proper sound of good quality on typical standard production TV sets in good repair; 
(b)  Transmit signals of adequate strength to produce good pictures with good sound at all outlets without causing cross modulation in the cables or interfering with other electrical or electronic systems; 
(c)  Limit failures to a minimum by locating and correcting malfunctions promptly, but in no event longer than 48 hours after notice; 
(d)  Demonstrate upon request by instruments or otherwise to subscribers that a signal of adequate strength and quality is being delivered. 
(2)  A grantee must at all times meet or exceed technical standards established by the Federal Communications Commission. 
(3)  The system shall be so constructed and operated that there is no significant deterioration in the quality of PEG access signals or leased access signals, either upstream or downstream, as compared with other channels on the system. Deterioration refers to any signal problem, including but not limited to ghost images and other interference and distortions. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:120. - Availability of facilities. 
(1)  Availability of cable service. 
(a)  A grantee shall offer service to all residences, businesses and other structures within the city, including multiple dwelling unit buildings, whose owners or occupants request cable service, except for (i) those residences, businesses and other structures that do not qualify under the line extension criteria specified in section 2:120(3), and (ii) multiple dwelling unit buildings to which the grantee cannot legally obtain access. 
(b)  The grantee shall provide service consistent with the requirements of 47 U.S.C. § 541(a)(3) (prohibiting redlining) and Chapter 112 of the City Code. 
(2)  The city may in a franchise agreement specify a construction schedule for a grantee. A grantee may refuse to provide cable service to property to which it does not have direct access from its distribution system because of physical or legal obstructions. 
(3)  Grantee shall extend cable service at then-prevailing standard installation charges to any unit or building upon request, so long as (a) the unit for which service is requested is located within 150 feet of the cable system; or (b) measuring from any 1 point on the system to the unit for which service is requested, there is an average density of 16 or more residential units per mile; or (c) the service is requested for a public school building located within the city. Individual residences in multiple dwelling units ("MDU") shall be included as individual "homes" in the count of homes per mile. However, the grantee shall not be required to count such residences or to extend its distribution system solely to serve an MDU that has not provided permission to the grantee to enter the property. 
(4)  In other cases, where the potential subscriber is located outside the 150-foot limit, the grantee shall also extend cable service, but the grantee may require the person or persons requesting service to agree to pay the actual material and labor costs incurred in extending service to their unit or units in excess of those the grantee is required to bear under this section. For example, if cable service is requested for a unit, and the average density to that unit is 9 units rather than 16 units per mile, the grantee must bear at least 9/16 of the actual cost of the extension, and may require the person requesting service to bear the remaining 7/16 of the cost. This line extension requirement may be waived in writing by the City Administrator for good cause shown. 
(5)  Grantee shall extend its cable system under section 2:120(3) to serve any requesting unit located within the franchise area within 90 days of the request. An exemption from this requirement is the "downtown" area of Ann Arbor, defined as the area bounded by Ashley, East Ann, North State and East Williams, where subject to construction conditions, cable service will be provided within 120 days, except as otherwise provided in the customer service standards as may now exist or may hereafter be established. Each deadline can be extended by the cable administrator for delays beyond the control of the grantee, including securing rights-of-way, construction permits and any other necessary authorizations. 
(6)  Unless otherwise specified in a franchise agreement, each grantee shall, without charge, upon the request of the city, provide 1 activated cable drop to connect each fire station in the city, each public elementary and secondary school within the city, and the Ann Arbor District Library (Main Branch) to the cable system, as well as up to 6 such activated drops, as requested by the city, for City Hall. The grantee shall not be required to make any such installation until it is requested to do so by the respective unit of government or educational institutions. The grantee shall provide basic service tiers 1, 2, and 3, or their equivalent (as such tiers were in effect on January 1, 2002), and any equipment necessary to receive such service, free of charge, to each such site. 
(7)  Continuity of service. 
(a)  A grantee shall use its best efforts to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous uninterrupted service. At the city's request, the grantee shall operate its system for a temporary period (the "transition period") following the termination of its franchise as necessary to maintain service to subscribers, and shall cooperate with the city to assure an orderly transition from it to another grantee. The transition period shall be no longer than the reasonable period required to ensure that cable service will be available to subscribers and that any institutional network remains available to the city, and shall not be longer than 24 months, unless extended by the city and the grantee for good cause. During the transition period, the grantee will continue to be obligated to comply with the terms and conditions of its franchise agreement and applicable laws and regulations. 
(b)  If a grantee abandons its system during the franchise term, or fails to operate its system in accordance with the terms of this agreement during any transition period, the city, at its option, may operate the system, designate another entity to operate the system temporarily until the grantee restores service under conditions acceptable to the city or until the franchise is revoked and a new grantee selected by the city is providing service, or obtain an injunction requiring the grantee to continue operations. If the city is required to operate or designate another entity to operate the cable system, the grantee shall reimburse the city or its designee for all reasonable costs and damages incurred that are in excess of the revenues from the cable system. 
(c)  Without limitation, the following examples would constitute abandonment for purposes of section 2:120(7)(b): a grantee fails or refuses to provide cable service in accordance with its franchise over a substantial portion of the franchise area for 96 consecutive hours, unless the city authorizes a longer interruption of service or the failure is due to force majeure as characterized in its franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:121. - Emergency use of facilities. 
(1)  Emergency alert. A cable system must be engineered, installed and maintained to provide an emergency alert system that complies with FCC regulations. 
(2)  Local alert. In addition, a cable system must allow certain authorized city and county officials to automatically override the audio and video signals of all channels on the cable system and transmit and report emergency information. Such overrides may be by means of (for example) direct telephone call-in by the city's emergency management division or by reception of wireless transmissions from the county emergency management division. The city shall contact any affected grantee when such an alert is triggered. The city and any grantee shall provide each other with contact persons who may be reached in case an alert is triggered. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:122. - Safety requirements. 
    All safety practices required by law shall be used by a grantee and its agents during construction, maintenance, and repair of the cable system. A grantee shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries or nuisance to the public. A grantee shall install and maintain its wires, cables, fixtures and other equipment in accordance with the requirements of the codes of the city and all codes adopted by reference therein and in such a manner that they will not interfere with any installations or property of the city or any properly placed property of any public utility serving the city. 
    All structures and all lines, equipment and connections in the city, wherever situated and located, shall at all times be kept and maintained by the grantee in a safe, suitable, substantial condition, and in good order and repair. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:123. - Conditions of street occupancy. 
(1)  All transmissions and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by a grantee in the city shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who abut any of the said public rights-of-way. 
(2)  In case of disturbance, or damage to any public right-of-way or other public or private property during the construction, repair, replacement, relocation, operation, maintenance, or reconstruction of a cable system, the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner to be approved by the City Administrator or other appropriate official delegated by him, replace and restore such public right-of-way or property in as good a condition as before the work done by grantee causing such disturbance or damage. 
(3)  If, at any time during the period of this franchise, the city shall lawfully elect to alter, repair, construct, or change the grade or location of any public right-of-way, to improve the public rights-of-way, or to construct, install, or repair any sewers, drains, pipes, power lines, or any other type of public works or government owned utility, or for any other purpose where the convenience of the city would be served thereby, a grantee shall, upon reasonable notice by the city, remove, relay, support, protect, temporarily disconnect, and/or relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes and other fixtures or any of its property, at its own expense. 
(4)  Any poles, or other fixtures or plant and equipment placed in any public rights-of-way by said grantee, shall be placed in such a manner as shall not unnecessarily hinder or obstruct usual vehicular or pedestrian travel on such public rights-of-way. 
(5)  A grantee shall, on request of any person holding a building permit issued by the city, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the movement of buildings. The expense of such temporary removal or raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting the same and the grantee shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. The grantee shall be given not less than 48 hours advance notice to arrange such temporary wire changes. 
(6)  The construction, operation, maintenance, and repair of the system shall be in accordance with all applicable sections of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, as amended; the Michigan Occupational Safety and Health Act, as amended; the most current edition of the National Electrical Safety Code and National Electric Code; the city's electrical code; Obstruction Marking and Lighting, AC 70/7460 i.e., Federal Aviation Administration; Construction, Marking and Lighting of Antenna Structures, Federal Communications Commission Rules Part 17; any other applicable federal, state, or local laws and regulations that may apply to the operation, construction, maintenance, or repair of a cable system, including, without limitation, local zoning and construction codes and laws and accepted industry practices, all as hereafter may be amended or adopted. In the event of a conflict among codes and standards, the most stringent code or standard shall apply (except insofar as those standard, if followed, would result in a system that could not meet requirements of federal, state or local law, or is expressly preempted by other such standards). The construction, operation, maintenance, and repair of the system shall be in accordance with good engineering practices. The grantee shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices preventing failures and accidents that are likely to cause damage, injury, or nuisance to the public. 
(7)  In the event of a failure by the grantee to complete any work required for the protection or restoration of the public rights-of-way, or any other work required by the City Code, within the time specified by and to the reasonable satisfaction of the city, the city, following notice and an opportunity to cure, may cause such work to be done, and the grantee shall reimburse the city the cost thereof within 30 days after receipt of an itemized list of such costs; or the city may recover such costs through the security fund provided by grantee. 
(8)  In the event of an emergency, or where a cable system creates or is contributing to an imminent danger to health, safety, or property, the city may remove, relay, or relocate any or all parts of that cable system without prior notice. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:124. - Transfer of franchise and change of control of grantee. 
(1)  No transfer shall occur unless prior application is made by a grantee to the city. Prior approval of the Council shall be required where control of a grantee is acquired by a person or group of persons or where the franchise is transferred to any other person or group of persons. If certain conditions precedent are met as set forth below, and if that person or group of persons is willing to accept such lawful covenants, terms and conditions as the city deems appropriate, such approval shall not be unduly withheld. 
(2)  At least 120 calendar days before the contemplated effective date of a transfer, the grantee shall submit to the city a written application for approval of the transfer. The application shall provide complete information on the proposed transaction, including without limitation details on the legal, financial, and technical qualifications of the transferee. At a minimum, the application shall include: 
(a)  FCC Form 394, or any successor form; 
(b)  A complete and un-redacted copy of the agreements to effectuate the proposed transaction and all schedules, exhibits, and other documents attached to them, and any documents referred to in them that are material to the proposed transaction or the grantee's operations in the city and are not otherwise publicly available, except as otherwise provided in section 2:124(3); 
(c)  Information relating to the legal, financial, and technical qualifications of the proposed transferee; 
(d)  A statement by the proposed transferee that the proposed transaction will have no material adverse financial impact on the grantee or the cable system, or, if such an adverse impact is anticipated, an explanation thereof; 
(e)  A statement of projected income, expense, and capital expenditures covering the lesser of 5 years or the remainder of the franchise term and explaining the assumptions upon which the projection is based; 
(f)  A general description of the anticipated management structure of the post-transfer cable system and of any financing to be used in connection with the proposed transaction; and 
(g)  A statement by the proposed transferee that the proposed transaction will have no material adverse impact on subscriber rates or service. 
(3)  Any transfer review period established by federal law will not begin until all documents and information required by section 2:124(2), without exception, have been provided to the city; provided, however, that the grantee may redact confidential, proprietary, or trade secret materials in the documents required by section 2:124(2)(b) if it satisfies the requirements of section 2:124(4). 
(4)  In the event that a grantee redacts material otherwise required by section 2:124(2)(b), it shall be the responsibility of the grantee at the time the application is filed to: (i) identify those materials redacted; (ii) provide a description of the information that would otherwise have appeared in the redacted materials; (iii) provide a reasonable confidentiality agreement which, if executed, would give the city immediate access to all the redacted material which, in the city's reasonable judgment, is material to the proposed transaction or the grantee's operations in the city. In the event that the city does not accept the confidentiality agreement offered by grantee, grantee shall take all reasonable steps to conclude with the city or its representatives, within 5 business days after submission of its application (the "confidentiality review period"), a confidentiality agreement allowing review of all redacted material subject to reasonable terms and conditions. If the city or its representatives and the grantee execute such an agreement within the confidentiality review period, then any transfer review period will begin at the time of execution, if the application is otherwise complete pursuant to applicable law. If the city or its representatives and the grantee do not execute such an agreement within the confidentiality review period, then the grantee and the city shall be deemed to have reserved all rights as to whether any transfer review period established by federal law has begun, except that in such case the grantee and the city shall be deemed to have agreed that no such review period began prior to the calendar day immediately following the confidentiality review period. 
(5)  Any transfer may be conditioned on the following, without limitation, at the city's discretion: 
(a)  The proposed transferee must agree to comply with all of the provisions of this chapter and the franchise agreement. 
(b)  The proposed transferee must resolve any reasonable objections to its financial, legal, or technical qualifications. 
(c)  Grantee's franchise fees, or any prorated portion thereof must be paid in full. 
(d)  All personal property taxes and other assessments levied by the federal, state or local municipality and due and owing must be paid in full or suitable provisions made for securing payment of the same. 
(e)  All violations of this chapter and the franchise agreement must be resolved. 
(f)  A transfer application submitted after the effective date of this chapter shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable filing fee, payable to the city, in the amount of $2,500.00. In addition, the city may, if consistent with applicable law, require the applicant to reimburse the city for its reasonable out-of-pocket expenses in considering the application, including consultants' fees, up to a maximum of $15,000.00 including the $2,500.00 filing fee. 
(6)  Encumbrancing of franchise. A grantee shall be entitled at its option and at any time or from time to time, without the necessity of obtaining the consent or approval of the city, to grant liens on or security interests in its right, title, interest in, to and under the franchise granted pursuant hereto and/or the assets and properties of the grantee's cable system, upon such terms, covenants and conditions as the grantee may agree upon with the party or parties to which such liens or security interests may be granted (such party or parties are hereinafter referred to as "secured parties"). In addition, any of the secured parties may, in connection with the grant of such liens and security interests, exercise all rights and remedies accruing to such secured parties under and pursuant to the security agreements and other instruments and documents executed and delivered by and between the grantee and secured parties, and, in addition thereto, all right and remedies of a secured party under the uniform commercial code and as otherwise available at law, including, without limitations, foreclosure, possession, and realization upon the grantee's right, title and interest in, to and under the franchise granted pursuant hereto, through the sale or other disposition of such franchise and the other encumbered property or otherwise, all without the necessity of obtaining any consent or approval of the city. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:125. - Removal of facilities. 
    Cable home wiring installed in residential single-family homes shall be owned by the property owner beginning at the time of installation. Upon termination of service to any subscriber, the subscriber or property owner may request a grantee to remove any aerial drop from the premises of such subscriber, and the grantee shall do so upon such request within 15 days. Cost of removal shall be borne by grantee. 
(Ord. No. 31-02, § 2, 8-5-02) 
2:126. - Customer service standards. 
(1)  During the franchise term, the city may, after giving all grantees an opportunity to comment, establish and enforce customer service standards for cable systems except as it is prohibited from doing so by federal or state law. In addition, a grantee shall at all times satisfy any additional or stricter requirements established by FCC regulations, or other applicable federal, state, or local laws, regulations, or written agreements with the city, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(2)  A grantee shall designate an agent in Ann Arbor responsible for the handling of service complaints. Subscribers shall be informed in writing by the grantee about procedures concerning the handling of complaints at the time of installation and at least once annually. A grantee must create a written record if a subscriber asks to speak with a supervisor while speaking with a customer service representative. Within 30 days after a written complaint from a subscriber, the grantee shall respond to such complaint, filing a complete copy of the complaint and the grantee's response with the cable administrator (with personally identifiable information redacted as may be necessary pursuant to federal law). 
(3)  Telephone and office availability. 
(a)  Each grantee shall maintain a local business office at a location in Ann Arbor, or at a mutually acceptable location in the Ann Arbor area, that shall be open at least from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, and at least 4 hours on weekends, to allow subscribers to request service, pay bills, make and resolve complaints and disputes, and conduct other business. 
(b)  Each grantee will maintain at least 1 local, toll-free or collect call telephone access line which will be available to subscribers 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Trained representatives of a grantee shall be available to respond to subscriber telephone inquiries at least from 9:00 a.m. to midnight Monday through Friday and at least 16 hours on weekends. Customer service operators shall identify themselves by at least their first names or company IDs immediately upon initial contact. 
(c)  Under normal operating conditions, the following standards shall be met by a grantee at least 90% of the time, measured quarterly. 
(i)  Telephone answering time shall not exceed 30 seconds, and the time to transfer the call to a customer service representative (including hold time) shall not exceed an additional 30 seconds. 
(ii)  A customer will receive a busy signal less than 3% of the time. 
(iii)  When no employee or agent of the grantee is available to answer a telephone, an answering machine or service capable of receiving and recording service complaints and inquiries shall be employed. Inquiries received after hours must be responded to by a trained representative of a grantee on the next business day. Any answering service employed by a grantee shall keep records of all service calls received and their disposition. 
(d)  A grantee must hire sufficient staff so that it can adequately respond to customer inquiries, complaints, and requests for service in its office, over the phone, and at the subscriber's residence. 
(4)  Scheduling and completing service. 
(a)  Prompt service. 
(i)  A grantee shall complete all installations located up to 125 feet from a grantee's existing distribution system within 7 business days after the order is placed. 
(ii)  A grantee shall complete all installations not located within 125 feet from a grantee's existing distribution system within the time periods specified in section 2:120(5). 
(iii)  A grantee shall commence repairs for system outages affecting more than 100 subscribers within 4 hours after the grantee becomes aware of the interruption, including Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. 
(iv)  A grantee shall commence repairs for all other service interruptions within 24 hours after the grantee becomes aware of the interruption, including Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. 
(v)  A grantee shall commence work on all requests for service other than service interruptions by the next business day after it receives the request for service or otherwise becomes aware of the need for service. 
(vi)  All service for a which a completion time is not otherwise specified in this section 2:126(4) must be completed within 3 days from the commencement of repairs, unless the customer requests a later date, or unless, for reasons beyond the grantee's control, the work could not be completed in those time periods even with the exercise of all due diligence, in which case the grantee shall complete the work in the shortest time possible. The failure of a grantee to hire sufficient staff or to properly train its staff shall not justify a grantee's failure to comply with this provision. 
(vii)  A grantee shall keep a maintenance service log indicating the nature of each service request, the date and time it was received, the disposition of said request and the time and date thereof. 
(b)  Service times. Each grantee shall perform service calls, installations, and disconnects at least from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Saturday. In addition, maintenance service capability enabling the prompt location and correction of major system malfunctions shall be available 7 days a week, 24 hours a day, including Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays. 
(c)  Appointments. The appointment window for installations, service calls, and other installation activities will be either a specific time or, at maximum, a 4-hour time block during the time from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Saturday. 
(d)  Cancellations. A grantee may not cancel an appointment with a subscriber after 6:00 p.m. on the business day preceding the appointment, unless the appointment is for a Monday, in which case the grantee may not cancel after 5:00 p.m. on Saturday. If a grantee's representative is running late for an appointment with a subscriber and will not be able to keep the appointment as scheduled, the subscriber will be contacted, and the appointment rescheduled, as necessary, at a time which is reasonably convenient for the subscriber. 
(e)  Other inquiries. Under normal operating conditions, billing inquiries and requests for service, repair, and maintenance not involving service interruptions must be acknowledged by a trained customer service representative prior to the end of the next business day, provided, however, that that time period for response to inquiries and requests via regular or electronic mail shall not begin to run until the next business day if such mail is not received during business hours, and that unless such mail is sent to an address publicly made available for customer inquiries or requests, the time shall not begin to run until the mail is reviewed by an individual recipient. A grantee shall respond to all other inquiries within 5 business days of the inquiry or complaint. 
(f)  Each grantee shall actively participate in customer service programs offered by the industry, such as NCTA's "on time guarantee," to compensate subscribers for missed appointments. In addition, a grantee shall honor reasonable requests by the cable administrator for credits up to $25.00 for missed appointments. 
(g)  Mobility-limited subscribers. With regard to mobility-limited subscribers, upon subscriber request, each grantee shall arrange for pickup and/or replacement of converters or other grantee equipment at the subscriber's address or by a satisfactory equivalent (such as the provision of a postage-prepaid mailer). 
(h)  Employee identification. A grantee shall provide standard identification documentation to all employees, including employees of subcontractors, who will be in contact with the public. Each such representative shall be required to wear an employee identification card issued by the grantee and bearing a picture of said employee. Such documents shall include a telephone number that can be used to verify all personnel, vehicles and other equipment operating under the authority of the grantee. 
(5)  Location of drops. In locations where the grantee's system must be underground, drops must be placed underground as well. Except as federal law may otherwise require, in any area where a grantee would be entitled to install a drop above-ground, the grantee will provide the homeowner the option to have the drop installed underground if requested, but may charge the homeowner the difference between the actual cost of the above-ground installation and the actual cost of the underground installation. 
(6)  Interruptions of service. A grantee may intentionally interrupt service on the cable system only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. If such an intentional interruption is expected to last for 2 hours or more, then the grantee must give all affected subscribers at least 48 hours' advance notice, except (a) in emergency situations, (b) to the extent necessary to fix the affected subscriber's service problems, or (c) if such notice would slow down the grantee's rectification of the problem. Interruptions associated wit h planned maintenance or construction that occurs between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. shall not require such notice to subscribers. 
(7)  Notice to subscribers. 
(a)  A grantee shall provide the following materials to each subscriber at the time cable service is installed, at least annually thereafter, and at any time upon request. Copies of all such materials provided to subscribers shall also be provided to the city. 
(i)  A written description of products and services offered, including prices, a list of channel positions, and a description of programming services, options, and conditions; 
(ii)  A written description of the grantee's installation and service maintenance policies; 
(iii)  Written instructions on how to use the cable service; 
(iv)  A written description of the grantee's billing and complaint procedures, including the address and telephone number of the city office responsible for receiving subscriber complaints; 
(v)  Notice regarding subscribers' privacy rights pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 551; 
(vi)  Notice that subscribers can purchase remote controls from retail outlets, and that a list of representative units compatible with the grantee's system is available on request.
