These expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses, such as attorney fees, and shall also include the reasonable value of any services rendered by or on behalf of the City Attorney, and the actual expenses of the city's agents, employees or expert witnesses, and disbursements and liability assumed by the city in connection with such suits, actions or proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 37-96, § 1, 4-21-97) 
2:309. - Standards and conditions of service; rules, regulations and rates. 
    The grantee is now under the jurisdiction of the Michigan Public Service Commission to the extent provided by statute; and the rates to be charged for gas, and the standards and conditions of service and operation in this city shall be the same as set forth in the grantee's schedule of rules, regulations, and rates as applicable in the several cities, villages, and townships in which the grantee is now rendering gas service, or as shall hereafter be validly prescribed for the City of Ann Arbor under the orders, rules, and regulations of the Michigan Public Service Commission or other authority having jurisdiction in the premises. 
(Ord. No. 37-96, § 1, 4-21-97) 
2:310. - City jurisdiction. 
    Grantee shall be and remain subject to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city now in effect or which may be subsequently adopted for the regulation of land uses or for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-96, § 1, 4-21-97) 
2:311. - Successors and assigns. 
(1)  The grantee may not sell, assign, sublet, or allow another to use the franchise granted by these sections 2:300-2:313 unless the City Council consents to same. If the grantee proposes to transfer or assign any interest of this franchise, written application for such transfer or assignment shall first be made to the city. The city may consider the technical, financial and fiscal capabilities, as well as the business history and any other information it, in its sole discretion, deems appropriate in evaluating the ability of any prospective successor, assignee or transferee to undertake the requirements of this franchise. The City Council will not unreasonably withhold approval after review. 
(2)  Subject to the provisions of the City Charter and section 2:311(1), the words "Michigan Consolidated Gas Company" and "grantee", are intended and shall be held and construed to mean and include both Michigan Consolidated Gas Company and its successors and assigns, as approved in writing by the city, whether so expressed or not. 
(Ord. No. 37-96, § 1, 4-21-97) 
2:312. - Franchise not exclusive. 
    The rights, power and authority granted by these sections 2:300-2:313 are not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 37-96, § 1, 4-21-97) 
2:313. - Franchise not retroactive. 
    The rights, powers and authority granted by these sections 2:300-2:313 are not retroactive and shall not be construed to authorize any installations or other actions of grantee which predate the effective date of these sections 2:300-2:313. 
(Ord. No. 37-96, § 1, 4-21-97) 
Chapter 37 - ENERGY UTILITY FRANCHISES 

2:600. - Energy utility franchises; definitions. 
    Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(1)  Applicant means an energy utility who has applied for an energy utility franchise pursuant to this chapter. 
(2)  Energy means electricity, natural gas and all similar materials which are used for lighting, heating, cooling and similar purposes. 
(3)  Energy utility means a person who transports, delivers or sells electric, natural gas, or similar energy to 1 or more customers through the use of facilities located in the public rights-of-way, or who otherwise transacts business in the city for the transportation and/or delivery of electric, natural gas, or similar energy. 
(4)  Energy utility franchise means a franchise granted to an energy utility by the City Council to allow the energy utility to operate an energy utility in the city and/or to transact business in the city. 
(5)  Facilities means any plant, works, systems, improvements and equipment owned, leased or used by an energy utility, including poles, wires, fixtures, underground circuits, conduits and other property used or installed in the public rights-of-way, which is necessary or convenient for the sale, transmission and/or distribution of energy to a customer or customers. 
(6)  Public rights-of-way means all public rights-of-way within the city which are owned by the city, either as an easement or in fee simple, and all other public places, including but not limited to the public rights-of-way used for streets, highways, sidewalks and alleys. 
(Ord. No. 44-97, § 1, 10-6-97) 
2:601. - Energy utility franchise required. 
    An energy utility may not transport, deliver or sell electric, natural gas, or similar energy to 1 or more customers through the use of facilities located in the public rights-of-way, and may not otherwise transact business in the city for the transportation and/or delivery of electric, natural gas, or similar energy, unless and until the energy utility has been granted an energy utility franchise by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 44-97, § 1, 10-6-97) 
2:602. - Application for franchise. 
    An energy utility who wishes to obtain an energy utility franchise from the city shall submit an application to the administrator or his/her designee. The administrator or designee may require that a particular form be used. The application must be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee of: 
(1)  $6,000.00 for electricity suppliers; 
(2)  $2,500.00 for suppliers of natural gas or other non-electric energy; 
(3)  $7,000.00 for suppliers of both electricity and natural gas or other non-electric energy; and 
(4)  Any additional $2,000.00 if the supplier expects to construct any facilities in the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 44-97, § 1, 10-6-97; Ord. No. 34-99, § 1, 8-2-99) 
2:603-2:609. - Reserved. 
2:610. - Grant of electric utility franchise. 
    Subject to all the terms and conditions set forth in these sections 2:610-2:632, the City of Ann Arbor grants to Nordic Electric, L.L.C., a Michigan limited liability company ("grantee"), a franchise to transmit, supply, deliver and distribute electricity and electrical services as part of a direct access program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and to transact related local business in the City of Ann Arbor. Provided, that this grant of franchise excludes a franchise to construct, lay, maintain or operate facilities, including but not limited to electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan; and further provided that grantee shall transmit, supply, deliver and distribute electricity and electrical services solely through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company, by agreement with the Detroit Edison Company or as otherwise provided by law. This grant of franchise also includes a franchise for grantee to own, operate and maintain metering and telemetry equipment for the purpose of serving its customers, provided that such equipment will not be used to bill services provided by the Detroit Edison Company. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:611. - Term of franchise. 
    The term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 is for 5 years after it takes effect, subject to revocation at the will of the City of Ann Arbor at any time during the 5-year period. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:612. - Electric service and extension of system. 
(1)  If the provisions and conditions of these sections 2:610-2:632 are accepted by the grantee, then the grantee may furnish electricity to customers located in the city under a direct access program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. Subject to the terms of this chapter, the grantee may from time to time extend its services and furnish electricity to any and all residents within the city in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. There are no limitations on the number of customers which the grantee may serve hereunder. However, the prohibition pertaining to construction in the second sentence of section 2:610 shall remain effective. 
(2)  Notwithstanding this grant, the grantee must comply with all provisions of the Code and rules and regulations of the city which regulate the use of public rights-of-way in the City of Ann Arbor, including but not limited to all permit requirements. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:613. - Franchise not exclusive. 
    The rights, power and authority granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 are not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:614. - Standards and conditions of service; rules, regulations and rates. 
    Grantee is now under the jurisdiction of the Michigan Public Service Commission to the extent provided by statute. Grantee shall comply with the standards and conditions of service and operation in this city which are validly prescribed for customers of grantee within the City of Ann Arbor under the orders, rules, and regulations of, the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency with authority and jurisdiction to issue or promulgate such orders, rules and regulations for grantee's service to customers in the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:615. - Use of streets and other public places. 
    No highway, street, alley, bridge, waterway or other public place used by the grantee shall be obstructed by the grantee in the performance of its business hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:616. - No city liability. 
(1)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable for any injury that may occur to any person, or for any damage that may occur to any property, as a result of any act, decision or other consequence or occurrence arising out of the discharge of his or her duties and responsibilities pursuant to sections 2:610-2:632. 
(2)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable for injury or damage occurring to any person or property from any cause whatsoever arising out of the construction, maintenance, repair, use, operation, condition or dismantling of any electric system owned or used by grantee and due to the act or omission of any person or entity other than the city. 
(3)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable to grantee or to grantee's customers for any interference with or disruption of the operation of any electric system owned or used by grantee or for any damage arising out of grantee's use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:617. - Indemnity. 
(1)  Grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense, defend, indemnify and hold harmless the city, all associated, affiliated allied and subsidiary entities of the city now existing or hereinafter created, and their respective officers, boards, commissions, employees, agents, attorneys, and contractors (hereinafter referred to as "indemnitees"), from and against any and all liability, obligation, damages, penalties, claims, liens, limitations, reasonable fees and expenses of attorneys, expert witnesses and consultants, which may be imposed upon, incurred by or be asserted against the indemnities by reason of any act or omission of grantee, its personnel, employees, agents, contractor or subcontractors, resulting in personal injury, bodily injury, sickness, disease or death to any person or damage to, loss of or destruction of tangible or intangible property libel, slander, invasion of privacy and unauthorized use of any trademark, trade name, copyright, patent, service mark of any other right of any person, firm or corporation which may arise out of or be in any way connected with the construction, installation, operation, maintenance or condition of any electric system owned or used by grantee or due to grantee's failure to comply with any federal, state or local statute, ordinance or regulation. 
(2)  Grantee undertakes and assumes for its officers, agents, contractors and subcontractors and employees, all risk of dangerous conditions, if any, on or about any city-owned or controlled property, including public rights-of-way, and grantee hereby agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the indemnities for personal injury or property damage to any person arising out of the installation, operation, maintenance or condition of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or due to grantee's failure to comply with any federal, state or local statute, ordinance or regulation. 
(3)  Notice, cooperation, and expenses. 
(a)  The city shall give grantee prompt notice of the making of any claim or the commencement of any action, suit or other proceeding covered by the provisions of this section 2:617. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall be deemed to prevent the city from cooperating with grantee and participating in the defense of any litigation by the city's own counsel. 
(c)  Grantee shall pay all expenses incurred by the city defending itself with regard to any such actions, suits or proceedings. These expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses, such as attorney fees, and shall also include the reasonable value of any services rendered by or on behalf of the City Attorney, and the actual expenses of the city's agents, employees or expert witnesses, and disbursements and liability assumed by the city in connection with such suits, actions or proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:618. - Insurance. 
(1)  During the term of this franchise, grantee shall maintain or cause to be maintained in full force and effect, and at its sole cost and expense, the following types and limits of insurance: 
(a)  Workers' compensation insurance with Michigan statutory limits, including employers' liability coverage. 
(b)  Comprehensive general liability insurance with minimum limits of $2,000,000.00 as the combined single limit for each occurrence of bodily injury and personal injury, and $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for property damage. The policy shall provide blanket contractual liability insurance for all written contracts, and shall include coverage for products and completed operations liability, independent contractors liability, broad form general liability extensions or equivalent, and coverage for property damage from perils of explosion, collapse or damage to underground utilities, commonly known as XCU coverage. 
(c)  Motor vehicle liability insurance covering all owned, hired, and non-owned vehicles in use by grantee, its employees and agents, with personal protection insurance and property protection insurance to comply with the provisions of the Michigan no fault insurance law, including residual liability insurance with minimum limits of $1,000,000.00 as the combined single limit for each occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. 
(2)  The policies required by subsections 2:618(1)(b) and (c) shall name the "City of Ann Arbor, including all elected and appointed officials, boards, commissions, officers and employees" as additional insureds (herein referred to in this chapter as the "additional insureds"). Each policy which is endorsed to add additional insureds hereunder shall contain cross-liability wording, as follows: 
"In the event of a claim being made hereunder by one insured for which another insured is or may be liable, then this policy shall cover such insured against whom a claim is or may be made in the same manner as if separate policies had been issued to each insured hereunder." 
(3)  The city may annually review the insurance coverage to be carried by grantee. If the city determines that additional or other insurance is necessary to protect the interests of the city or the additional insureds, the city will notify grantee and grantee shall obtain the additional types and limits of insurance, at its sole cost and expense. 
(4)  All insurance shall be effected under valid and enforceable policies, insured by insurers licensed to do business by the state of Michigan or by surplus line carriers on the Michigan insurance commissioner's approved list of companies qualified to do business in Michigan. All insurance carriers and surplus line carriers shall be rated A or better by A.M. Best Company. 
(5)  Certificates showing grantee has, and continues to have in effect during the term of this franchise the insurance policies required by this section 2:618, along with written evidence of payment of required premiums, shall be filed with the city. The insurance certificates for each policy required to be maintained by this franchise shall contain an unconditional endorsement that the insurer will give the city at least 30 days prior written notice of any intention not to renew the policy or to cancel, replace or materially alter the policy. 
(6)  Grantee shall require that each and every one of its contractors and their subcontractors carry, in full force and effect, workers' compensation, comprehensive general liability and motor vehicle liability insurance coverage of the same type and amounts grantee is required to obtain under this section 2:618. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:619. - Public emergency. 
    The city shall have the right to sever, disrupt, dig up or otherwise destroy facilities owned or used by grantee, without any prior notice, if such action is deemed necessary by the Director of Public Services, Director of Utilities, Fire Chief, Police Chief, or City Administrator because of a public emergency. Public emergency shall be any condition which, in the opinion of any of the officials named, possesses an immediate threat to the lives or property of the residents of the city, caused by any natural or manmade disaster, including but not limited to storms, floods, fire, accidents, explosions, major water main breaks, hazardous material spills, etc. Grantee or the owner of the facilities shall be responsible for repair, at its sole expense, of the facilities damaged pursuant to any such action taken by the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:620. - City jurisdiction. 
    Grantee shall be and remain subject to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city now in effect or which may be subsequently adopted for the regulation of land uses or for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:621. - State and federal regulatory agencies. 
(1)  As to all other conditions and elements of service not addressed or fixed by this ordinance, grantee shall be subject to the rules and regulations applicable to electric service by the Michigan Public Service Commission or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction, and shall be subject to the rules and regulations applicable to electric service by any federal agency. 
(2)  Grantee shall provide the city with copies of all documents which grantee sends to the Michigan Public Service Agency, or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction, and copies of all orders, decisions, or correspondence which grantee receives from the Michigan Public Service Agency, or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction. Grantee shall permit the city to inspect and examine all records grantee is required to maintain or file under the rules and regulations of the Michigan Public Service Agency, or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction. 
(3)  Grantee also shall provide the city with copies of all documents which grantee sends to any federal agency with regulatory authority over the transmission, distribution or other provision of electric services. Grantee shall permit the city to inspect and examine all records grantee is required to maintain or file under the rules and regulations of such federal agency. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:622. - Information required to be provided to customers. 
    Grantee shall provide all its customers in the city with the following information: 
(1)  Price information - including average annualized cents per kilowatt hour measured at the customer's meter, price variability information by time of use and volume, and all charges, fees and penalties; 
(2)  Terms of service - including length and kind of contract, billing policies, warranties and notice procedures; 
(3)  Customer service information - including a contact address, telephone number and procedures for obtaining and maintaining service and for making complaints; and 
(4)  Fuel and emissions characteristics - information on the fuel mix and emissions characteristics associated with the grantee's load-serving resource portfolio. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:623. - Portfolio of renewable energy sources; option to purchase greater percentage of power from renewable energy sources; prohibition against degradation of quality of energy sources. 
(1)  During the first year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:610-2:632, grantee will obtain at least 3% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, but not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(2)  During the second year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:610-2:632, grantee will obtain at least 4% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, but not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(3)  During the third year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:610-2:632, grantee will obtain at least 6% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, but not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(4)  During the fourth year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:610-2:632, grantee will obtain at least 8% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, but not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(5)  During the fifth year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:610-2:632, grantee will obtain at least 10% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, but not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(6)  If grantee fails or is unable to meet the requirements of subsections 2:623(1) through (5), it shall make payment in the amount of $.015 for each kWh grantee is short of its requirement to a 501(c)(3) or other similarly designated non-profit entity whose mission statement shall include the receipt and distribution of monies dedicated to promoting energy efficiency and energy education projects in Ann Arbor. Selection of the entity shall be subject to the approval of the City Administrator or his designee. measurement of grantee's provision of energy from renewable sources shall be done on a calendar year basis. Payment under this section 2:623(2) shall be made on or before March 31 following the end of the calendar year for which the calculation is made. In the event that a payment is not paid when due, interest will be added to the unpaid amount until paid in full, with interest calculated at a rate equal to 9% per annum. Acceptance of payment under this subsection shall not limit or inhibit any other right of the city. 
(7)  Definition and verification of renewable source requirement. 
(a)  For purposes of this section 2:623, the percentage of electricity from renewable sources supplied to customers in the city shall mean the ratio of the electric energy from renewable resources supplied by or under contract to customers within the city, measured in kWh, to the total electric energy supplied by grantee by or under contract to customers in the city, measured in kWh. 
(b)  To the extent grantee participates in wholesale settlements with other suppliers and/or a pool, its total supply from renewable sources shall include its pro rata share of renewable supplies provided to the pool and/or the settlement process and supplied to customers in the city from the pool and/or the settlement process. 
(c)  Upon request from the city, grantee shall provide the city with a list of plants or other facilities from which it obtained electric energy, whether directly or through a wholesale settlement or pool, and for each plant and facility listed, shall provide documentation verifying the amount and the fuel source(s) of the kWh generated. 
(d)  Verification and certification of the renewable energy sales percentages of grantee will be done by an independent third party which is in the business of certifying purchases of energy from renewable energy sources. Selection of the third party will be subject to the approval of the city. Grantee will pay for the services of the third party. 
(8)  Grantee shall offer to all its customers in the city the option to purchase a portion of their power greater than the percentages required by subsections 2:623(1) through (5) as power which is non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, power produced by renewable energy sources such as, but not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Any such additional power from renewable sources purchased by customers shall not be included as power from renewable sources in the calculation required by section 2:623(3), but shall be included in the calculation as part of the total power supplied to customers. 
(9)  Because the city is committed to reducing global warming emissions, any power sold by grantee to customers in Ann Arbor after the effective date of the franchise granted by sections 2:610-2:632 must not result in an increase in CO 2 emissions. For purposes of this subsection 2:623(9), grantee shall be in compliance if the average annual CO 2 emissions from the generation mix of power sold by grantee to customers in Ann Arbor does not exceed 1,963 lbs./MWh. grantee's computation and methodology for computing its average annual CO 2 emissions from the generation mix of power sold by Grantee to customers in Ann Arbor during the preceding calendar year shall be included in the annual performance report required by section 2:626. 
(10)  False reporting of the information required or requested by this section 2:623 shall be grounds for termination of the franchise granted by sections 2:610-2:632. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:624. - Partnership with the city for the city's energy plan. 
    Grantee agrees to partner with the city to advance the goals of the Ann Arbor Energy Plan and of the Energy Commission of the City of Ann Arbor by participating in projects and programs mutually agreed upon by grantee and the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:625. - Extremely low income customers; contribution to Ann Arbor Assistance Fund. 
(1)  For purposes of this section 2:625, "extremely low income" is defined as 30% of median income, for the number of persons in the family unit. 
(2)  Grantee agrees to contribute to the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund a payment of 0.12% of grantee's aggregate gross revenues received for the provision of electrical services within the city during the term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632, or $25,000.00, whichever amount is greater. 
(a)  The foregoing amount may be paid as a single payment during the first year of the franchise, or may be paid in 5 installments of $5,000.00 each during the term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632; provided, however, that at the end of each year of the franchise, if 0.12% of the aggregate gross revenues received by the grantee for the provision of electrical services within the city during that year exceeds $5,000.00, then grantee shall, within 90 days after the end of the year, pay into the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund the difference between $5,000.00 and the amount calculated as 0.12% of the aggregate gross revenues received by the grantee for the provision of electrical services within the city during the year. For purposes of this section 2:625(2)(a), the end of each year shall be the day immediately preceding the same day of the same month of each year as the effective date of the franchise, as set by section 2:632(1). 
(b)  Payment of the single payment during the first year shall be paid within 30 days after the effective date of the franchise, as set by section 2:632(1). 
(c)  Payment of the first installment under this section 2:625 shall be made on or before within 30 days after the effective date of the franchise, as set by section 2:632(1). Each subsequent installment shall be paid on or before the same day of the same month that the first installment was due in each of the following 4 years during the term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632. 
(d)  In the event the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 is terminated earlier than the 5-year term set by section 2:611, any remaining installments which have not yet been paid shall become immediately due and grantee agrees that it will pay the total amount of such installments within 30 days following notice of termination of the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632. 
(e)  In the event that a payment is not paid when due, interest will be added to the unpaid amount until paid in full, with interest calculated at a rate equal to 9% per annum. Acceptance of payment under this subsection shall not limit or inhibit any other right of the city. 
(3)  The City Administrator or designee and a designated representative of grantee will establish procedures for the method of transmitting grantee's contribution to the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund, including verification of the aggregate gross revenues received by the grantee during the preceding year and determination of the amount of any overpayments or underpayments due to subsequent corrections in the grantee's books of account. 
(4)  If the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor state agency with similar jurisdiction prescribes a tariff for electric energy available to extremely low income customers in Michigan, or in the City of Ann Arbor, Grantee shall offer a rate for service to such customers that is no greater than the state-approved tariff, but which may be less to meet the goal of universal affordable electric service in the City of Ann Arbor. 
(5)  The payment by grantee to the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund under this section 2:625 is not, and shall not be construed as, a periodic franchise fee for any purpose. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:626. - Annual performance report. 
    On or before March 31 of each year, grantee shall submit to the city's Energy Office an annual report which describes grantee's activity in the city for the preceding calendar year (January 1-December 31). The report must include the following information: 
(1)  Total energy sales quantities, revenues and number of customers, separated into industrial, commercial and residential classes; 
(2)  Resource portfolio and emissions characteristics associated with energy supplied to customers in the city during the preceding calendar year, including information on the fuel mix and emissions characteristics associated with the grantee's load-serving resource portfolio; 
(3)  Grantee's computation and methodology for computing its average annual CO 2 , SO 2 and NOx emissions from the generation mix of power sold by grantee to customers in Ann Arbor during the preceding calendar year; 
(4)  Activities or programs provided within the city which have contributed to the city's energy goals as defined by the city's energy plan or by the energy commission of the City of Ann Arbor; and 
(5)  Other contributions to the city and to the residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:627. - Successors and assigns. 
(1)  The grantee may not sell, assign, sublet, or allow another to use the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 unless the City Council consents to same. If the grantee proposes to transfer or assign any interest of this franchise, written application for such transfer or assignment shall first be made to the City. The city may consider the technical, financial and fiscal capabilities, as well as the business history and any other information it, in its sole discretion, deems appropriate in evaluating the ability of any prospective successor, assignee or transferee to undertake the requirements of this franchise. The City Council will not unreasonably withhold approval after review. 
(2)  Subject to the provisions of the City Charter and section 2:627(1), the words "Nordic Electric, L.L.C." and "grantee", are intended and shall be held and construed to mean and include both Nordic Electric, L.L.C., and its successors and assigns, as approved in writing by the city, whether so expressed or not. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:628. - Annual or periodic fees. 
(1)  Grantee agrees to abide by any future ordinance(s) of the city, if and when formally adopted and effective, which may require the payment by grantee of a fee, charge or other payment on a periodic basis (such as monthly, quarterly, annually), provided that any such future ordinance(s) apply equally to all electric utility franchise holders. The city shall notify grantee in writing within 45 days after the effective date of such an ordinance, at which time the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 shall be automatically amended to include the requirement that grantee make such periodic payments unless grantee, within 30 days after such notice unless grantee notifies the city in writing that it will not make the payments, in which case the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 shall be automatically revoked. Any new franchise granted to grantee by the city shall be subject to the provisions of such future ordinance(s) and shall require payment of such fee or periodic charge, or a payment substantially equivalent thereto, as a condition of the new franchise. 
(2)  In the event that grantee, or any company which is a subsidiary, affiliate, or other related company to grantee, pays a fee, charge, or other payment of any kind on a periodic basis (such as monthly, quarterly, annually), to any municipality in the State of Michigan as a condition, or in consideration for, the right to conduct a utility business in that municipality, grantee shall notify the city in writing of the details of the fee or periodic charge within 60 days of the effective date of the fee or periodic charge, at which time the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 shall be automatically amended to include the requirement that grantee make such periodic payments unless grantee, within 30 days after such notice, notifies the city in writing that it will not make the payments, in which case the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 shall be automatically revoked. Any new franchise granted to grantee by the city shall require payment by grantee of a similar fee or periodic charge, or a payment substantially equivalent thereto, as a condition of the new franchise. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:629. - Franchise not retroactive. 
    The rights, powers and authority granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 are not retroactive and shall not be construed to authorize any installations or other actions of grantee which predate the effective date of these sections 2:610-2:632. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:630. - Notice of loss of right to use facilities. 
    If grantee terminates, forfeits, defaults or otherwise loses its right to transmit, supply, deliver and distribute electricity and electrical services through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company, then grantee shall notify the City Administrator in writing within 14 days and grantee's rights under the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 shall be suspended for 30 days following receipt of said notice. At the end of the 30 days, the franchise will be terminated unless grantee has regained its right to transmit, supply, deliver and distribute electricity and electrical services through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company and has provided the City Administrator with notice that it has regained that right. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:631. - Penalties. 
    Any violation by the grantee of any provision of the franchise set forth in these sections 2:610-2:632, or any material portion thereof, shall be cause for forfeiture of this franchise and all rights hereunder to the city after written notice to grantee and continuation of such violation, failure or default. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:632. - Conditions for franchise to become effective or cease. 
(1)  The terms and conditions of the franchise contained in these sections 2:610-2:632 shall become effective when both of the following have occurred: 
(a)  The City Clerk shall deliver to the grantee a certified copy of this ordinance accompanied by written evidence of publication and recording thereof as required by law and grantee shall file with the City Clerk its written and unconditional acceptance of the conditions and provisions thereof within 30 days from the date of adoption; and 
(b)  Grantee has Michigan Public Service Commission certification(s) empowering it to sell electricity within the City of Ann Arbor, Michigan. 
(2)  If either of the conditions stated in section 2:632(1)(a) and (b) does not occur, the franchise contained in sections 2:610-2:632 shall cease and be of no effect. 
(3)  The terms and conditions of the franchise granted by these sections 2:610-2:632 must become effective within 1 year after the adoption of this ordinance or it shall cease and be of no effect. 
(Ord. No. 37-98, § 1, 3-19-99) 
2:633-2:634. - Reserved. 
2:635. - Grant of electric utility franchise. 
    Subject to all the terms and conditions set forth in these sections 2:635-2:657, the City of Ann Arbor grants to Engage Energy US, L.P., a Delaware limited partnership ("Grantee"), a franchise to supply electricity and electrical services as part of a program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and to transact related local business in the City of Ann Arbor. Provided, that this grant of franchise excludes a franchise to construct, lay, maintain or operate facilities, including but not limited to electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan; and further provided that grantee shall supply electricity and electrical services solely through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company, by agreement with the Detroit Edison Company or as otherwise provided by law. This grant of franchise also includes a franchise for grantee to own, operate and maintain metering and telemetry equipment for the purpose of serving its customers, provided that such equipment will not be used to bill services provided by the Detroit Edison Company. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:636. - Term of franchise. 
    The term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 is for 5 years after it takes effect, subject to revocation at the will of the City of Ann Arbor at any time during the 5-year period. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:637. - Electric service and extension of system. 
(1)  If the provisions and conditions of these sections 2:635-2:657 are accepted by the grantee, then the grantee may furnish electricity to customers located in the city under a program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. Subject to the terms of this chapter, the grantee may from time to time extend its services and furnish electricity to any and all residents within the city in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. There are no limitations on the number of customers which the grantee may serve hereunder. However, the prohibition pertaining to construction in the second sentence of section 2:635 shall remain effective. 
(2)  Notwithstanding this grant, the grantee must comply with all provisions of the Code and rules and regulations of the city which regulate the use of public rights-of-way in the City of Ann Arbor, including but not limited to all permit requirements, to the extent applicable. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:638. - Franchise not exclusive. 
    The rights, power and authority granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 are not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:639. - Standards and conditions of service; rules, regulations and rates. 
    Grantee is now under the jurisdiction of the Michigan Public Service Commission to the extent provided by statute. Grantee shall comply with the standards and conditions of service and operation in this city which are validly prescribed for customers of grantee within the City of Ann Arbor under the orders, rules, and regulations of, the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency with authority and jurisdiction to issue or promulgate such orders, rules and regulations for grantee's service to customers in the city. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:640. - Use of streets and other public places. 
    No highway, street, alley, bridge, waterway or other public place used by the grantee shall be obstructed by the grantee in the performance of its business hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:641. - No city liability. 
(1)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable for any injury that may occur to any person, or for any damage that may occur to any property, as a result of any act, decision or other consequence or occurrence arising out of the discharge of his or her duties and responsibilities pursuant to sections 2:635-2:657. 
(2)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable for injury or damage occurring to any person or property from any cause whatsoever arising out of the construction, maintenance, repair, use, operation, condition or dismantling of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, and due to the act or omission of any person or entity other than the city. 
(3)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable to grantee or to grantee's customers for any interference with or disruption of the operation of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, or for any damage arising out of grantee's use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:642. - Indemnity. 
(1)  Grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense, defend, indemnify and hold harmless the city, all associated, affiliated allied and subsidiary entities of the city now existing or hereinafter created, and their respective officers, boards, commissions, employees, agents, attorneys, and contractors (hereinafter referred to as "Indemnitees"), from and against any and all liability, obligation, damages, penalties, claims, liens, limitations, reasonable fees and expenses of attorneys, expert witnesses and consultants, which may be imposed upon, incurred by or be asserted against the indemnities by reason of any act or omission of grantee, its personnel, employees, agents, contractor or subcontractors, resulting in personal injury, bodily injury, sickness, disease or death to any person or damage to, loss of or destruction of tangible or intangible property libel, slander, invasion of privacy and unauthorized use of any trademark, trade name, copyright, patent, service mark of any other right of any person, firm or corporation which may arise out of or be in any way connected with the construction, installation, operation, maintenance or condition of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, or due to grantee's failure to comply with any federal, state or local statute, ordinance or regulation. 
(2)  Grantee undertakes and assumes for its officers, agents, contractors and subcontractors and employees, all risk of dangerous conditions, if any, on or about any city-owned or controlled property, including public rights-of-way, and grantee hereby agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the indemnities for personal injury or property damage to any person arising out of the installation, operation, maintenance or condition of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, or due to grantee's failure to comply with any federal, state or local statute, ordinance or regulation. 
(3)  Notice, cooperation, and expenses. 
(a)  The city shall give grantee prompt notice of the making of any claim or the commencement of any action, suit or other proceeding covered by the provisions of this section 2:642. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall be deemed to prevent the city from cooperating with grantee and participating in the defense of any litigation by the city's own counsel. 
(c)  Grantee shall pay all expenses incurred by the city defending itself with regard to any such actions, suits or proceedings. These expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses, such as attorney fees, and shall also include the reasonable value of any services rendered by or on behalf of the City Attorney, and the actual expenses of the city's agents, employees or expert witnesses, and disbursements and liability assumed by the city in connection with such suits, actions or proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:643. - Insurance. 
(1)  During the term of this franchise, grantee shall maintain or cause to be maintained in full force and effect, and at its sole cost and expense, the following types and limits of insurance: 
(a)  Workers' compensation insurance with Michigan statutory limits, including employers' liability coverage. 
(b)  Comprehensive general liability insurance with minimum limits of $2,000,000.00 as the combined single limit for each occurrence of bodily injury and personal injury, and $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for property damage. The policy shall provide blanket contractual liability insurance for all written contracts, and shall include coverage for products and completed operations liability, independent contractors liability, broad form general liability extensions or equivalent, and coverage for property damage from perils of explosion, collapse or damage to underground utilities, commonly known as XCU coverage. 
(c)  Motor vehicle liability insurance covering all owned, hired, and non-owned vehicles in use by grantee, its employees and agents, with personal protection insurance and property protection insurance to comply with the provisions of the Michigan no fault insurance law, including residual liability insurance with minimum limits of $1,000,000.00 as the combined single limit for each occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. 
(2)  The policies required by subsections 2:643(1)(b) and (c) shall name the "City of Ann Arbor, including all elected and appointed officials, boards, commissions, officers and employees" as additional insureds (herein referred to in this chapter as the "additional insureds"). Each policy which is endorsed to add additional insureds hereunder shall contain cross-liability wording, as follows: 
"In the event of a claim being made hereunder by 1 insured for which another insured is or may be liable, then this policy shall cover such insured against whom a claim is or may be made in the same manner as if separate policies had been issued to each insured hereunder." 
(3)  The city may annually review the insurance coverage to be carried by grantee. If the city determines that additional or other insurance is necessary to protect the interests of the city or the additional insureds, the city will notify grantee and grantee shall obtain the additional types and limits of insurance, at its sole cost and expense. 
(4)  All insurance shall be effected under valid and enforceable policies, insured by insurers licensed to do business by the State of Michigan or by surplus line carriers on the Michigan insurance commissioner's approved list of companies qualified to do business in Michigan. All insurance carriers and surplus line carriers shall be rated A or better by A.M. Best Company 
(5)  Certificates showing grantee has, and continues to have in effect during the term of this franchise the insurance policies required by this section 2:643, along with written evidence of payment of required premiums, shall be filed with the city. The insurance certificates for each policy required to be maintained by this franchise shall contain an unconditional endorsement that the insurer will give the city at least 30 days prior written notice of any intention not to renew the policy or to cancel, replace or materially alter the policy. 
(6)  Grantee shall require that each and every 1 of its contractors and their subcontractors carry, in full force and effect, workers' compensation, comprehensive general liability and motor vehicle liability insurance coverage of the same type and amounts grantee is required to obtain under this section 2:643. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:644. - Public emergency. 
    The city shall have the right to sever, disrupt, dig up or otherwise destroy facilities owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, without any prior notice, if such action is deemed necessary by the Director of Public Services, Director of Utilities, Fire Chief, Police Chief, or City Administrator because of a public emergency. Public emergency shall be any condition which, in the opinion of any of the officials named, possesses an immediate threat to the lives or property of the residents of the city, caused by any natural or man-made disaster, including but not limited to storms, floods, fire, accidents, explosions, major water main breaks, hazardous material spills, etc. The owner of the facilities shall be responsible for repair, at its sole expense, of the facilities damaged pursuant to any such action taken by the city. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:645. - City jurisdiction. 
    To the extent applicable, grantee shall be and remain subject to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city now in effect or which may be subsequently adopted for the regulation of land uses or for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:646. - State and federal regulatory agencies. 
(1)  As to all other conditions and elements of service not addressed or fixed by this ordinance, grantee shall be subject to the rules and regulations applicable to electric service by the Michigan Public Service Commission or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction, and shall be subject to the rules and regulations applicable to electric service by any federal agency. 
(2)  Grantee shall provide the city with copies of all documents related to services provided under the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657 which grantee sends to the Michigan Public Service Commission, or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction, and copies of all orders, decisions, or correspondence related to services provided under the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657 which grantee receives from the Michigan Public Service Commission, or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction. Grantee shall permit the city to inspect and examine all records related to services provided under the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657 which grantee is required to maintain or file under the rules and regulations of the Michigan Public Service Commission, or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction. 
(3)  Grantee also shall provide the city with copies of all documents related to services provided under the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657 which grantee sends to any federal agency with regulatory authority over the transmission, distribution or other provision of electric services. Grantee shall permit the city to inspect and examine all records related to services provided under the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657 which grantee is required to maintain or file under the rules and regulations of such federal agency. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:647. - Information required to be provided to customers. 
    Grantee shall provide all its customers in the city with the following information: 
(1)  Price information - including average annualized cents per kilowatt hour measured at the customer's meter, price variability information by time of use and volume, and all charges, fees and penalties; 
(2)  Terms of service - including length and kind of contract, billing policies, warranties and notice procedures; 
(3)  Customer service information - including a contact address, telephone number and procedures for obtaining and maintaining service and for making complaints; and 
(4)  Fuel and emissions characteristics - information on the fuel mix and emissions characteristics associated with the grantee's load-serving resource portfolio. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:648. - Portfolio of renewable energy sources; option to purchase greater percentage of power from renewable energy sources; prohibition against degradation of quality of energy sources. 
(1)  During the first year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657, grantee will obtain at least 3% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, and not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(2)  During the second year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657, grantee will obtain at least 4% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, and not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(3)  During the third year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657, grantee will obtain at least 6% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, and not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(4)  During the fourth year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657, grantee will obtain at least 8% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, and not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(5)  During the fifth year of the 5-year term of the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657, grantee will obtain at least 10% of the electricity (expressed in kWh) supplied to customers in the city from sources which are non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, electricity produced by renewable energy sources such as, and not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Excess kWh may be banked for use in the year next following the year in which they are generated. 
(6)  If grantee fails or is unable to meet the requirements of subsections 2:648(1) through (5), it shall make payment in the amount of $.015 for each kWh grantee is short of its requirement to a 501(c)(3) or other similarly designated non-profit entity whose mission statement shall include the receipt and distribution of monies dedicated to promoting energy efficiency and energy education projects in Ann Arbor. Selection of the entity shall be subject to the approval of the City Administrator or his or her designee. Measurement of grantee's provision of energy from renewable sources shall be done on a calendar year basis. Payment under this section 2:648(2) shall be made on or before March 31 following the end of the calendar year for which the calculation is made. In the event that a payment is not paid when due, interest will be added to the unpaid amount until paid in full, with interest calculated at a rate equal to 9% per annum. Acceptance of payment under this subsection shall not limit or inhibit any other right of the city. 
(7)  Definition and Verification of Renewable Source Requirement. 
(a)  For purposes of this section 2:648, the percentage of electricity from renewable sources supplied to customers in the city shall mean the ratio of the electric energy from renewable resources supplied by or under contract to customers within the city, measured in kWh, to the total electric energy supplied by grantee by or under contract to customers in the city, measured in kWh. 
(b)  To the extent grantee participates in wholesale settlements with other suppliers and/or a pool, its total supply from renewable sources shall include its pro rata share of renewable supplies provided to the pool and/or the settlement process and supplied to customers in the city from the pool and/or the settlement process. 
(c)  Upon request from the city, grantee shall provide the city with a list of plants or other facilities from which it obtained electric energy, whether directly or through a wholesale settlement or pool, and for each plant and facility listed, shall provide documentation verifying the amount and the fuel source(s) of the kWh generated. 
(d)  Verification and certification of the renewable energy sales percentages of grantee will be done by an independent third party which is in the business of certifying purchases of energy from renewable energy sources. Selection of the third party will be subject to the approval of the city. Grantee will pay for the services of the third party. 
(8)  Grantee shall offer to all its customers in the city the option to purchase a portion of their power greater than the percentages required by subsections 2:648(1) through (5) as power which is non-nuclear and non-fossil fuel based power, but which is, instead, power produced by renewable energy sources such as, and not limited to, solar, wind, hydro, or biomass energy sources. Any such additional power from renewable sources purchased by customers shall not be included as power from renewable sources in the calculation required by section 2:648(3), but shall be included in the calculation as part of the total power supplied to customers. 
(9)  Because the city is committed to reducing global warming emissions, any power sold by grantee to customers in Ann Arbor after the effective date of the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657 must not result in an increase in CO 2 emissions. For purposes of this subsection 2:648(9), grantee shall be in compliance if the average annual CO 2 emissions from the generation mix of power sold by grantee to customers in Ann Arbor does not exceed 1,963 lbs./MWh. Grantee's computation and methodology for computing its average annual CO 2 emissions from the generation mix of power sold by grantee to customers in Ann Arbor during the preceding calendar year shall be included in the annual performance report required by section 2:651. 
(10)  False reporting of the information required or requested by this section 2:648 shall be grounds for termination of the franchise granted by sections 2:635-2:657. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:649. - Cooperation with the city for the city's energy plan. 
    Grantee agrees to cooperate with the city to advance the goals of the Ann Arbor Energy Plan and of the Energy Commission of the City of Ann Arbor by participating in projects and programs mutually agreed upon by grantee and the city. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:650. - Extremely low income customers; contribution to Ann Arbor Assistance Fund 
(1)  For purposes of this section 2:650, "extremely low income" is defined as 30% of median income, for the number of persons in the family unit. 
(2)  Grantee agrees to contribute to the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund a payment of 0.12% of grantee's aggregate gross revenues received for the provision of electrical services within the city during the term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657, or $5,000.00, whichever amount is greater. 
(a)  The foregoing amount may be paid as a single payment during the first year of the franchise, or may be paid in 5 installments of $1,000.00 each during the term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657; provided, however, that at the end of each year of the franchise, if 0.12% of the aggregate gross revenues received by the Grantee for the provision of electrical services within the city during that year exceeds $1,000.00, then grantee shall, within 90 days after the end of the year, pay into the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund the difference between $1,000.00 and the amount calculated as 0.12% of the aggregate gross revenues received by the grantee for the provision of electrical services within the city during the year. For purposes of this section 2:650(2)(a), the end of each year shall be the day immediately preceding the same day of the same month of each year as the effective date of the franchise, as set by section 2:657(1). 
(b)  Payment of the single payment during the first year shall be paid within 30 days after the effective date of the franchise, as set by section 2:657(1). 
(c)  Payment of the first installment under this section 2:650 shall be made on or before within 30 days after the effective date of the franchise, as set by section 2:657(1). Each subsequent installment shall be paid on or before the same day of the same month that the first installment was due in each of the following 4years during the term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657. 
(d)  In the event the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 is terminated earlier than the (5-year term set by section 2:636, any remaining installments which have not yet been paid shall be set at $1,000.00 each and shall become immediately due and grantee agrees that it will pay the total amount of such installments within 30 days following notice of termination of the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657. 
(e)  In the event that a payment is not paid when due, interest will be added to the unpaid amount until paid in full, with interest calculated at a rate equal to 9% per annum. Acceptance of payment under this subsection shall not limit or inhibit any other right of the city. 
(3)  The City Administrator or designee and a designated representative of grantee will establish procedures for the method of transmitting grantee's contribution to the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund, including verification of the aggregate gross revenues received by the grantee during the preceding year and determination of the amount of any overpayments or underpayments due to subsequent corrections in the grantee's books of account. 
(4)  If the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor state agency with similar jurisdiction prescribes a tariff for electric energy available to extremely low income customers in Michigan, or in the City of Ann Arbor, and if grantee supplies electric service to residential customers, grantee shall offer a rate for service to such extremely low income customers that is no greater than the state-approved tariff, but which may be less to meet the goal of universal affordable electric service in the City of Ann Arbor. 
(5)  The payment by grantee to the Ann Arbor Assistance Fund under this section 2:650 is not, and shall not be construed as, a periodic franchise fee for any purpose. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:651. - Annual performance report. 
    On or before March 31 of each year, grantee shall submit to the city's Energy Office an annual report which describes grantee's activity in the city for the preceding calendar year (January 1-December 31). The report must include the following information: 
(1)  Total energy sales quantities, revenues and number of customers, separated into industrial, commercial and residential classes; 
(2)  Resource portfolio and emissions characteristics associated with energy supplied to customers in the city during the preceding calendar year, including information on the fuel mix and emissions characteristics associated with the grantee's load-serving resource portfolio; 
(3)  Grantee's computation and methodology for computing its average annual CO 2 , SO 2 and NOx emissions from the generation mix of power sold by grantee to customers in Ann Arbor during the preceding calendar year. 
(4)  Activities or programs provided within the city which have contributed to the city's energy goals as defined by the city's energy plan or by the Energy Commission of the City of Ann Arbor; and 
(5)  Other contributions to the city and to the residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:652. - Successors and assigns. 
(1)  The grantee may not sell, assign, sublet, or allow another to use the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 unless the City Council consents to same. If the grantee proposes to transfer or assign any interest of this franchise, written application for such transfer or assignment shall first be made to the city. The city may consider the technical, financial and fiscal capabilities, as well as the business history and any other information it, in its sole discretion, deems appropriate in evaluating the ability of any prospective successor, assignee or transferee to undertake the requirements of this franchise. The City Council will not unreasonably withhold approval after review. 
(2)  Subject to the provisions of the City Charter and section 2:652(1), the words "Engage Energy US, L.P." and "grantee", are intended and shall be held and construed to mean and include both Engage Energy US, L.P., and its successors and assigns, as approved in writing by the city, whether so expressed or not. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:653. - Annual or periodic fees. 
    Grantee agrees to abide by any future ordinance(s) of the city, if and when formally adopted and effective, which may require the payment by grantee of a fee, charge or other payment on a periodic basis (such as monthly, quarterly, annually), provided that any such future ordinance(s) apply equally to all electric utility franchise holders whose franchises exclude a franchise to construct, lay, maintain or operate facilities, including but not limited to electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan; and who supply electricity and electrical services solely through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company, by agreement with the Detroit Edison Company or as otherwise provided by law. The city shall notify grantee in writing within 45 days after the effective date of such an ordinance, at which time the franchise granted by these Sections 2:635-2:657 shall be automatically amended to include the requirement that Grantee make such periodic payments unless grantee, within 30 days after such notice unless grantee notifies the city in writing that it will not make the payments, in which case the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 shall be automatically revoked. Any new franchise granted to grantee by the city shall be subject to the provisions of such future ordinance(s) and shall require payment of such fee or periodic charge, or a payment substantially equivalent thereto, as a condition of the new franchise. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:654. - Franchise not retroactive. 
    The rights, powers and authority granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 are not retroactive and shall not be construed to authorize any installations or other actions of grantee which predate the effective date of these sections 2:635-2:657. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:655. - Notice of loss of right to use facilities. 
    If grantee terminates, forfeits, defaults or otherwise loses its right to supply electricity and electrical services through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company, then grantee shall notify the City Administrator in writing within 14 days and grantee's rights under the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 shall be suspended for 30 days following receipt of said notice. At the end of the 30 days, the franchise will be terminated unless grantee has regained its right to supply electricity and electrical services through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company and has provided the City Administrator with notice that it has regained that right. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:656. - Penalties. 
    Any violation by the grantee of any provision of the franchise set forth in these sections 2:635-2:647, or any material portion thereof, shall be cause for forfeiture of this franchise and all rights hereunder to the city after written notice to grantee and continuation of such violation, failure or default. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:657. - Conditions for franchise to become effective or cease. 
(1)  The terms and conditions of the franchise contained in these sections 2:635-2:657 shall become effective when both of the following have occurred: 
(a)  The City Clerk shall deliver to the grantee a certified copy of this ordinance accompanied by written evidence of publication and recording thereof as required by law and grantee shall file with the City Clerk its written and unconditional acceptance of the conditions and provisions thereof within 30 days from the date of adoption; and 
(b)  Grantee has Michigan Public Service Commission certification(s) empowering it to sell electricity within the City of Ann Arbor, Michigan. 
(2)  If either of the conditions stated in section 2:657(1)(a) and (b) does not occur, the franchise contained in sections 2:635-2:657 shall cease and be of no effect. 
(3)  The terms and conditions of the franchise granted by these sections 2:635-2:657 must become effective within 1 year after the adoption of this ordinance or it shall cease and be of no effect. 
(Ord. No. 41-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
2:658, 2:659. - Reserved. 
2:660. - Grant of electric utility franchise. 
    Subject to all the terms and conditions set forth in these sections 2:660-2:682, the City of Ann Arbor grants to DTE Energy Marketing, Inc., a Michigan corporation ("grantee"), a franchise to supply electricity and electrical services as part of a program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and to transact related local business in the City of Ann Arbor. Provided, that this grant of franchise excludes a franchise to construct, lay, maintain or operate facilities, including but not limited to electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan; and further provided that grantee shall supply electricity and electrical services solely through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company, by agreement with the Detroit Edison Company or as otherwise provided by law. This grant of franchise also includes a franchise for grantee to own, operate and maintain metering and telemetry equipment for the purpose of serving its customers, provided that such equipment will not be used to bill services provided by the Detroit Edison Company. 
(Ord. No. 50-99, § 1, 1-3-00) 
2:661. - Term of franchise. 
    The term of the franchise granted by these sections 2:660-2:682 is for 5 years after it takes effect, subject to revocation at the will of the City of Ann Arbor at any time during the 5-year period. 
(Ord. No. 50-99, § 1, 1-3-00) 
2:662. - Electric service and extension of system. 
(1)  If the provisions and conditions of these sections 2:660-2:682 are accepted by the grantee, then the grantee may furnish electricity to customers located in the city under a program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. Subject to the terms of this chapter, the grantee may from time to time extend its services and furnish electricity to any and all residents within the city in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. There are no limitations on the number of customers which the grantee may serve hereunder. However, the prohibition pertaining to construction in the second sentence of section 2:660 shall remain effective. 
(2)  Notwithstanding this grant, the grantee must comply with all provisions of the Code and rules and regulations of the city which regulate the use of public rights-of-way in the City of Ann Arbor, including but not limited to all permit requirements, to the extent applicable. 
(Ord. No. 50-99, § 1, 1-3-00) 
2:663. - Franchise not exclusive. 
    The rights, power and authority granted by these sections 2:660-2:682 are not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 50-99, § 1, 1-3-00) 
2:664. - Standards and conditions of service; rules, regulations and rates. 
    Grantee is now under the jurisdiction of the Michigan Public Service Commission to the extent provided by statute. Grantee shall comply with the standards and conditions of service and operation in this city which are validly prescribed for customers of grantee within the City of Ann Arbor under the orders, rules, and regulations of, the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency with authority and jurisdiction to issue or promulgate such orders, rules and regulations for grantee's service to customers in the city. 
(Ord. No. 50-99, § 1, 1-3-00) 
2:665. - Use of streets and other public places. 
    No highway, street, alley, bridge, waterway or other public place used by the grantee shall be obstructed by the grantee in the performance of its business hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 50-99, § 1, 1-3-00) 
2:666. - No city liability. 
(1)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable for any injury that may occur to any person, or for any damage that may occur to any property, as a result of any act, decision or other consequence or occurrence arising out of the discharge of his or her duties and responsibilities pursuant to sections 2:660-2:682. 
(2)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable for injury or damage occurring to any person or property from any cause whatsoever arising out of the construction, maintenance, repair, use, operation, condition or dismantling of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, and due to the act or omission of any person or entity other than the city. 
(3)  The city, its officials, employees and agents shall not be liable to grantee or to grantee's customers for any interference with or disruption of the operation of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, or for any damage arising out of grantee's use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 50-99, § 1, 1-3-00) 
2:667. - Indemnity.
